Overview

Andes DSP Library User Manual contains information about the specifications of digital signal processing (DSP) functions in Andes DSP library (libdsp) for ISA V5 toolchains and describes how to use these functions.

Andes DSP library provides comprehensive functions designed to simplify and accelerate the development of digital signal processing systems, ensuring high code efficiency and streamlined code size. These functions include basic operations for vectors, matrices, and complex vectors, as well as functions that compute advanced algorithms such as filtering and transform functions.

Designed and developed with toolchains from Andes BSP v5.0 and later versions, Andes DSP library provides easy-to-use APIs to encapsulate the complexity of calculations when processing signals. It benefits you to save development resources, focus on your system and reduce development time.

The functions in Andes DSP library are organized into the following categories: basic math, complex, controller, filtering, matrix, statistics, transform, utility, Support Vector Machine (SVM) estimation, distance, sorting, interpolation, quaternion, and window functions. For detailed descriptions of each category, see List of Functions.

To call the library functions, simply include header files provided by Andes DSP library. These header files define prototypes and instance structures of functions. They are named according to the function categories, as listed below:

  • riscv_dsp_basic_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_complex_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_controller_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_filtering_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_matrix_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_statistics_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_transform_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_utils_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_svm_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_distance_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_sort_math.h

  • riscv_dsp_interp.h

  • riscv_dsp_quaternion.h

  • riscv_dsp_window.h

For example, to use basic functions for operations with vectors, you can include riscv_dsp_basic_math.h in your C files.

Note that controller functions are implemented directly in the header file riscv_dsp_controller_math.h for better performance. To optimize them with the DSP ISA Extension, ensure you apply the compiler flag -mext-dsp to enable the toolchain support.

Andes DSP library defines several data types to properly store signal data for later processing. These data types, defined in riscv_dsp_math_types.h, are as follows:

typedef int8_t q7_t;         /* Q7 type */
typedef uint8_t u8_t;        /* U8 type */
typedef int16_t q15_t;       /* Q15 type */
typedef uint16_t u16_t;      /* U16 type */
typedef int32_t q31_t;       /* Q31 type */
typedef uint32_t u32_t;      /* U32 type */
typedef int64_t q63_t;       /* Q63 type */
typedef uint64_t u64_t;      /* U64 type */
typedef float float32_t;     /* single-precision floating-point (F32) type */
typedef double float64_t;    /* double-precision floating-point (F64) type */
typedef _Float16 float16_t;  /* half-precision floating-point (F16) type */
Note

If your application uses functions involving the half-precision floating-point data type, compile it with the
-mzfh option and ensure that your toolchain (e.g., v5f or v5d toolchain) supports HW FPU.

This application can only run on targets with HW FPU support. Failure to do so may cause issues during execution.

Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains

In addition to the above header files, different linking options are required depending on the toolchain in use. Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains describes the options for Newlib and MCUlib toolchains.

Table 1. Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains
Option Description

-ldsp

Links Andes DSP library (libdsp.a)

-mext-dsp

Enables the DSP ISA Extension

-mext-zc

Enables the Code Size Reduction Extension

-lm

Links the libm math library

-mzfh

Enables the half-precision floating-point data type and Zfh Extension

-mtune=andes-45-series

Enables a more efficient library on Andes 45-series cores

Apply the -lm option directly to ensure the functionality of Andes DSP library functions that involve math functions from the libm library.

If your target system does not support the DSP ISA Extension for accelerating the DSP library, use the -ldsp option to link your application against Andes DSP library (libdsp.a).

For systems with DSP ISA Extension support, use the -ldsp -mext-dsp options to enable the extension and achieve better performance. Similarly, if the Code Size Reduction Extension is available, use the -mext-zc option to reduce code size.

Note

When targeting AndesCore 45-series processors, you can use the -mtune=andes-45-series option to enable optimizations specialized for these processors.

For applications using half-precision floating-point data types (e.g., riscv_dsp_log_f16), ensure that your toolchain (e.g., v5f or v5d toolchain) supports HW FPU:

  • Compile with the -mzfh option to enable both compiler and linker support for half-precision floating-point data types (_Float16) used in the DSP library.

  • Without the -mzfh option, compilation will fail.

In addition, to prevent potential issues when loading the program, be aware of the following:

  • An application built with -ldsp -mext-dsp or -mext-zc cannot be executed on a target that lacks support for the DSP ISA Extension or Code Size Reduction Extension.

  • An application built with -mzfh cannot be executed on a target that lacks support for HW FPU.

Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains

Options for Glibc Toolchains describes the available options for Glibc toolchains.

Table 2. Options for Glibc Toolchains
Option Description

-static

Applies static linking

-ldsp

Links Andes DSP library libdsp.a without DSP ISA Extension

-ldsp_p

Links Andes DSP library libdsp.a with DSP ISA Extension.
For backward compatibility, the previous -ldsp_hw option is retained as a symbolic link to -ldsp_p.

-mext-zc

Enables the Code Size Reduction Extension

-lm

Links the libm math library

-mzfh

Enables the half-precision floating-point data type and Zfh Extension

-mtune-andes-45-series

Enables a more efficient library on Andes 45-series cores.
This option is only available for glibc toolchains in AndeSight versions prior to v5.4.

Static and dynamic linking require different options. Linking Options for Different Types summarizes the required linking options needed based on the type of linking and the application’s requirement for extension support.

Table 3. Linking Options for Different Types
Linking Type DSP ISA Extension Linking Options

Static Linking

Without

-static -ldsp

With

-static -ldsp_p

Dynamic Linking (default)

Without

-ldsp

With

-ldsp_p

For target systems supporting the DSP ISA Extension, use the -static -ldsp_p and -ldsp_p options. For targets without DSP ISA Extension support, use -static -ldsp and -ldsp. Ensure that you specify the options appropriate for your target system.

If the Code Size Reduction Extension is available in your system, use the -mext-zc option to reduce code size.

Note

When targeting AndesCore 45-series processors and using a glibc toolchain from an AndeSight version earlier than v5.4, you can optionally use the -mtune=andes-45-series option to enable optimizations specialized for these processors.

For applications using half-precision floating-point data types (e.g., riscv_dsp_log_f16), ensure that your toolchain (e.g., v5f or v5d toolchain) supports HW FPU:

  • Compile with the -mzfh option to enable both compiler and linker support for half-precision floating-point data types (_Float16) used in the DSP library.

  • Without the -mzfh option, compilation will fail.

In addition, to prevent potential issues when loading the program, be aware of the following:

  • An application built with -mext-zc cannot be executed on a target that lacks support for the Code Size Reduction Extension.

  • An application built with -mzfh cannot be executed on a target that lacks support for HW FPU.

Data Alignment for Andes DSP Library Functions

Andes DSP library V5 functions are designed for 32-bit Andes V5 CPU cores to use 4-byte aligned data and for 64-bit Andes V5 CPU cores to use 8-byte aligned data.

That is, they assume the base memory addresses of input arrays, including input source arrays and output destination arrays, are aligned to 4-byte or 8-byte boundaries.

These functions are implemented to load/store one word regardless of the type of input pointer, then process with SIMD DSP instructions to deliver high performance.

Accessing a word from a misaligned memory location is referred to as a misaligned memory access. On CPUs that do not support misaligned accesses, this results in an Address Misaligned exception. However, on CPUs that support and enable misaligned accesses, such operations do not trigger an exception but may cause slight performance degradation.

For detailed descriptions of how Andes V5 CPUs handle misaligned accesses, see AndeStar V5 Architecture and CSR Definitions.

Among the data types supported by Andes DSP library V5 functions, Q31 and F32 are 4-byte data types, naturally aligned at 4-byte addresses when declared. Similarly, Q15 and Q7, being 2-byte and 1-byte data types respectively, are aligned at 2-byte and 1-byte addresses by default.

To avoid misaligned memory access on 32-bit Andes V5 CPU cores, you must explicitly declare that input arrays are accessed at 4-byte aligned addresses for the following data types: Q15 and Q7. For example:

q7_t inputA[blocksize] __attribute__ ((aligned(4)));
q15_t outputvec[blocksize] __attribute__ ((aligned(4)));

On the other hand, to avoid misaligned memory access on 64-bit Andes V5 CPU cores, you must explicitly declare the 8-byte alignment for the following data types: Q31, Q15, Q7, and F32. For example:

q7_t inputA[blocksize] __attribute__ ((aligned(8)));
q15_t outputvec[blocksize] __attribute__ ((aligned(8)));
q31_t source[blocksize] __attribute__ ((aligned(8)));
float32_t source[blocksize] __attribute__ ((aligned(8)));

The following functions do not require explicit declaration of aligned accesses on 32-bit or 64-bit Andes V5 CPU cores:

  • Controller functions

  • Conversion functions

  • Arc tangent functions

  • Arc tangent 2 functions

  • Cosine functions

  • Sine functions

  • Square root functions

Additionally, for 32-bit Andes V5 CPU cores only, the following functions do not require explicit declaration of aligned accesses:

  • Functions using input arrays of F32 data type

  • Functions using input arrays of Q31 data type

Backward Compatibility

Andes DSP library continues to support the previous function prefix, nds_, for backward compatibility. If your application uses nds_ prefixed functions, ensure that the corresponding header files are included. These header files automatically convert the nds_ prefix to riscv_dsp_ during compilation. The header files, categorized by function type, are as follows:

  • nds_basic_math.h

  • nds_complex_math.h

  • nds_controller_math.h

  • nds_filtering_math.h

  • nds_matrix_math.h

  • nds_statistics_math.h

  • nds_transform_math.h

  • nds_utils_math.h

For example, to use basic functions prefixed with nds_ in your program, include nds_basic_math.h in your C files.

List of Functions

Andes DSP Library Function List categorizes all functions of Andes DSP library and includes a Supported Since column. This column uses numbers to indicate the BSP or AndeSight (AST) version in which each function first became available:

  • 1 = BSP v5.0.0 or AST v3.2.0 Beta

  • 2 = AST v3.2.1

  • 3 = AST v5.0.0

  • 4 = AST v5.1.0

  • 5 = AST v5.2.0

  • 6 = AST v5.3.0

  • 7 = AST v5.4.0

Table 4. Andes DSP Library Function List
Category Function Supported Since

riscv_dsp_win_hft116d_f32

7

riscv_dsp_win_hft116d_f64

7

Hft144d Window Functions

riscv_dsp_win_hft144d_f32

7

riscv_dsp_win_hft144d_f64

7

Hft169d Window Functions

riscv_dsp_win_hft169d_f32

7

riscv_dsp_win_hft169d_f64

7

Hft196d Window Functions

riscv_dsp_win_hft196d_f32

7

riscv_dsp_win_hft196d_f64

7

Hft223d Window Functions

riscv_dsp_win_hft223d_f32

7

riscv_dsp_win_hft223d_f64

7

Hft248d Window Functions

riscv_dsp_win_hft248d_f32

7

riscv_dsp_win_hft248d_f64

7

Basic Functions

This section includes the following basic functions.

Absolute Functions

These functions compute the absolute values of elements from a source vector and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = (src[n] < 0) \, ? \, -src[n] \, : \, src[n];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_abs_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_abs_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_abs_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_abs_f16 (float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_abs_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_abs_f64 (float64_t * src, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_abs_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_abs_q31 (q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0, 0x7FFFFFFF].

  • If the input value is INT32_MIN (0x80000000), the output value is INT32_MAX (0x7FFFFFFF).

riscv_dsp_abs_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_abs_q15 (q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0, 0x7FFF].

  • If the input value is INT16_MIN (0x8000), the output value is INT16_MAX (0x7FFF).

riscv_dsp_abs_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_abs_q7 (q7_t * src, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0, 0x7F].

  • If the input value is INT8_MIN (0x80), the output value is INT8_MAX (0x7F).

Addition Functions

These functions add two elements from separate source vectors and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src1[n] + src2[n];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_add_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_add_f32 (float32_t * src1, float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_add_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_add_f16 (float16_t * src1, float16_t * src2, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_add_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_add_f64 (float64_t * src1, float64_t * src2, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_add_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_add_q31 (q31_t * src1, q31_t * src2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q31 range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF].

riscv_dsp_add_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_add_q15 (q15_t * src1, q15_t * src2, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q15 range [0x8000, 0x7FFF].

riscv_dsp_add_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_add_q7 (q7_t * src1, q7_t * src2, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q7 range [0x80, 0x7F].

riscv_dsp_add_u8_u16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_add_u8_u16 (uint8_t * src1, uint8_t * src2, uint16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The result of two uint8_t data is saved in uint16_t format.

Division Functions

These functions divide two elements from separate source vectors/scalars and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector/scalar.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src1[n] / src2[n];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point and Q31. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_div_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_div_f32 (float32_t * src1, float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector (dividend vector)

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector (divisor vector)

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector (quotient vector)

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_div_q31

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_div_q31 (q31_t src1, q31_t src2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Dividend value

[in] src2

Divisor value
Returns

The quotient value

Note

  • The absolute value of src1 must be less than that of src2.

  • This function deals with scalars, not vectors.

riscv_dsp_div_u64_u32

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_div_u64_u32 (uint64_t src1, uint32_t src2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Dividend value

[in] src2

Divisor value
Returns

The quotient value

Note

  • The value of src1, right-shifted by 31 bits, must be less than that of src2; otherwise, the result is invalid.

  • This function deals with scalars, not vectors.

riscv_dsp_div_s64_u32

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_div_s64_u32 (q63_t src1, uint32_t src2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Dividend value

[in] src2

Divisor value
Returns

The quotient value

Note

  • The value of src1, right-shifted by 31 bits, must be less than that of src2; otherwise, the result is invalid.

  • This function deals with scalars, not vectors.

Dot Product Functions

These functions calculate the dot product of two vectors and store the results in a destination output.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (output = 0, \, \, n = 0; \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{output += src1[n] * src2[n];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_dprod_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_dprod_f32 (float32_t * src1, float32_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

riscv_dsp_dprod_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_dprod_f16 (float16_t * src1, float16_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_dprod_f64

Declaration
float64_t riscv_dsp_dprod_f64 (float64_t * src1, float64_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

riscv_dsp_dprod_q31

Declaration
q63_t riscv_dsp_dprod_q31 (q31_t * src1, q31_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

Note

The format of the returned values is Q48, and the type is q63_t.

riscv_dsp_dprod_q15

Declaration
q63_t riscv_dsp_dprod_q15 (q15_t * src1, q15_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

Note

The format of the returned values is Q30, and the type is q63_t.

riscv_dsp_dprod_q7

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_dprod_q7 (q7_t * src1, q7_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

Note

The format of the returned values is Q14, and the type is q31_t.

riscv_dsp_dprod_u8

Declaration
uint32_t riscv_dsp_dprod_u8 (uint8_t * src1, uint8_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

Note

This function multiplies a uint8_t datum by another uint8_t datum and adds the result to a uint32_t accumulator.

riscv_dsp_dprod_u8xq15

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_dprod_u8xq15 (uint8_t * src1, q15_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

Note

This function multiplies a uint8_t datum by a q15_t datum and adds the result to a q31_t accumulator.

riscv_dsp_dprod_q7xq15

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_dprod_q7xq15 (q7_t * src1, q15_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The dot product of the two input vectors

Note

This function multiplies a q7_t datum by a q15_t datum and adds the result to a q31_t accumulator.

Multiplication Functions

These functions multiply two elements from separate vectors and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src1[n] * src2[n];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mul_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mul_f32 (float32_t * src1, float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_mul_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mul_f16 (float16_t * src1, float16_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mul_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mul_f64 (float64_t * src1, float64_t * src2, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_mul_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mul_q31 (q31_t * src1, q31_t * src2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q31 range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF].

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mul_q15 (q15_t * src1, q15_t * src2, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q15 range [0x8000, 0x7FFF].

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mul_q7 (q7_t * src1, q7_t * src2, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q7 range [0x80, 0x7F].

riscv_dsp_mul_u8_u16

void riscv_dsp_mul_u8_u16 (uint8_t * src1, uint8_t * src2, uint16_t * dst, uint32_t size)

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The result of two uint8_t data is saved in uint16_t format.

Negate Functions

These functions negate the elements of a source vector and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = -src[n];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_neg_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_neg_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_neg_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_neg_f16 (float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_neg_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_neg_f64 (float64_t * src, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_neg_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_neg_q31 (q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0x80000001, 0x7FFFFFFF].

  • If the input value is INT32_MIN (0x80000000), the output value is INT32_MAX (0x7FFFFFFF).

riscv_dsp_neg_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_neg_q15 (q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0x8001, 0x7FFF].

  • If the input value is INT16_MIN (0x8000), the output value is INT16_MAX (0x7FFF).

riscv_dsp_neg_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_neg_q7 (q7_t * src, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0x81, 0x7F].

  • If the input value is INT8_MIN (0x80), the output value is INT8_MAX (0x7F).

Offset Functions

These functions add a constant number to each element of a source vector and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src[n] + offset;} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_offset_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_offset_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t offset, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] offset

Constant offset value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_offset_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_offset_f16 (float16_t * src, float16_t offset, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] offset

Constant offset value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_offset_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_offset_f64 (float64_t * src, float64_t offset, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] offset

Constant offset value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_offset_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_offset_q31 (q31_t * src, q31_t offset, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] offset

Constant offset value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q31 range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF].

riscv_dsp_offset_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_offset_q15 (q15_t * src, q15_t offset, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] offset

Constant offset value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q15 range [0x8000, 0x7FFF].

riscv_dsp_offset_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_offset_q7 (q7_t * src, q7_t offset, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] offset

Constant offset value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q7 range [0x80, 0x7F].

riscv_dsp_offset_u8

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_offset_u8 (uint8_t * src, q7_t offset, uint8_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] offset

Constant offset value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the uint8_t range [0x00, 0xFF].

Scale Functions

These functions multiply each element of a source vector by a constant scaling value and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src[n] + scale;} \end{aligned} \]

In cases of fractional representation, a parameter shift is introduced to adjust the range of result values. For details about the parameter, see the functions with fractional data types in riscv_dsp_scale_f16 to riscv_dsp_scale_u8.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_scale_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_scale_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t scale, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] scale

Constant scaling value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Example
#define size    2
float32_t src[size] = {0.8167, 0.5};
float32_t dst[size] = {0};
float32_t scale = 0.4;

riscv_dsp_scale_f32 (src, scale, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8 scale functions.

riscv_dsp_scale_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_scale_f16 (float16_t * src, float16_t scale, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] scale

Constant scaling value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_scale_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_scale_f64 (float64_t * src, float64_t scale, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] scale

Constant scaling value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_scale_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_scale_q31 (q31_t * src, q31_t scale_fract, int8_t shift, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] scale_fract

Constant fractional scaling value

[in] shift

Bits for result adjustment

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • Due to fractional representation, the results should fall within the Q31 range. You can use the input parameter shift to adjust the result values, where the shift value can range from 0 to 31 in this function.

  • The behavior of this function is approximately described by the formula:

    dst[n] = (src[n] * scale_fract) >> (31 - shift)

    where 0 ≤ n < size and 0 ≤ shift ≤ 31.

riscv_dsp_scale_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_scale_q15 (q15_t * src, q15_t scale_fract, int8_t shift, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] scale_fract

Constant fractional scaling value

[in] shift

Bits for result adjustment

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • Due to fractional representation, the results should fall within the Q15 range. You can use the input parameter shift to adjust the result values, where the shift value can range from 0 to 15 in this function.

  • The behavior of this function is approximately described by the formula:

    dst[n] = (src[n] * scale_fract) >> (15 - shift)

    where 0 ≤ n < size and 0 ≤ shift ≤ 15.

riscv_dsp_scale_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_scale_q7 (q7_t * src, q7_t scale_fract, int8_t shift, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] scale_fract

Constant fractional scaling value

[in] shift

Bits for result adjustment

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • Due to fractional representation, the results should fall within the Q7 range. You can use the input parameter shift to adjust the result values, where the shift value can range from 0 to 7 in this function.

  • The behavior of this function is approximately described by the formula:

    dst[n] = (src[n] * scale_fract) >> (7 - shift)

    where 0 ≤ n < size and 0 ≤ shift ≤ 7.

riscv_dsp_scale_u8

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_scale_u8 (uint8_t * src, q7_t scale_fract, int8_t shift, uint8_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] scale_fract

Constant fractional scaling value

[in] shift

Bits for result adjustment

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • Since the data type for the destination vector is uint8_t, the scaled results are saturated to the uint8_t range [0x00, 0xFF]. You can use the input parameter shift to adjust the result values, where the shift value can range from 0 to 7 in this function.

  • The behavior of this function is approximately described by the formula:

    dst[n] = (src[n] * scale_fract) >> (7 - shift)

    where 0 ≤ n < size and 0 ≤ shift ≤ 7.

Shift Functions

These functions shift each element in a source vector by a constant shift value and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

A positive shift value moves elements to the left, while a negative shift value moves them to the right.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \mathtt{\{} \\ & \quad \mathtt{if \ (shift < 0)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src[n] \, >> \, (-shift);} \\ & \quad \mathtt{else} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src[n] \, << \, (shift);} \\ & \mathtt{\}} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_shift_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_shift_q31 (q31_t * src, int8_t shift, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] shift

Signed shift value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • Due to performance considerations, the shift value must not exceed 32; otherwise, the result may be incorrect.

  • The results are saturated to the Q31 range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF].

Example
#define size    1024
q31_t src[size] = {...};
q31_t dst[size];
q31_t shift = 1;

riscv_dsp_shift_q31 (src, shift, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q15, Q7, and U8 shift functions.

riscv_dsp_shift_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_shift_q15 (q15_t * src, int8_t shift, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] shift

Signed shift value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • Due to performance considerations, the shift value must not exceed 16; otherwise, the result may be incorrect.

  • The results are saturated to the Q15 range [0x8000, 0x7FFF].

riscv_dsp_shift_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_shift_q7 (q7_t * src, int8_t shift, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] shift

Signed shift value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • Due to performance considerations, the shift value must not exceed 24; otherwise, the result may be incorrect.

  • The results are saturated to the Q7 range [0x80, 0x7F].

riscv_dsp_shift_u8

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_shift_u8 (uint8_t * src, int8_t shift, uint8_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] shift

Signed shift value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • Due to performance considerations, the shift value must not exceed 24; otherwise, the result may be incorrect.

  • The results are saturated to the uint8_t range [0x00, 0xFF].

Subtraction Functions

These functions subtract two elements from separate source vectors and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src1[n] - src2[n];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_sub_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_sub_f32 (float32_t * src1, float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_sub_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_sub_f16 (float16_t * src1, float16_t * src2, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Bitwise NOT Functions

These functions compute the logical bitwise NOT values of elements in a source vector and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: U32, U16, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

Elementwise Clipping Functions

These functions constrain the values of elements in a source vector to be within two bounds and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_clip_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_clip_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, float32_t low, float32_t high, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the first input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] low

Lower bound

[in] high

Higher bound

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_clip_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_clip_f16 (float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, float16_t low, float16_t high, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the first input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] low

Lower bound

[in] high

Higher bound

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

[in] high

Fixed-Point Division Functions

These functions divide a numerator by a denominator to calculate a quotient value normalized between -1.0 and 1.0. Additionally, a shift-left value is output to obtain the unnormalized quotient.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: Q31 and Q15. The functions are introduced in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_divide_q31

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_divide_q31 (q31_t numerator, q31_t denominator, q31_t  * quotient, int16_t * shift)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] numerator

Numerator value

[in] denominator

Denominator value

[out] quotient

Pointer to the output quotient

[out] shift

Pointer to the output shift
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if the division fails due to a denominator of zero

riscv_dsp_divide_q15

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_divide_q15 (q15_t numerator, q15_t denominator, q15_t  * quotient, int16_t * shift)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] numerator

Numerator value

[in] denominator

Denominator value

[out] quotient

Pointer to the output quotient

[out] shift

Pointer to the output shift
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if the division fails due to a denominator of zero

Absolute Difference Functions

These functions compute the absolute difference values of elements in a source vector and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \mathtt{\{} \\ & \quad \mathtt{diff = src1[n] - src2[n];} \\ & \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = (diff < 0) \, ? \, -diff : diff;} \\ & \mathtt{\}} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_absdiff_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_absdiff_f32 (float32_t * src1, float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_absdiff_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_absdiff_f16 (float16_t * src1, float16_t * src2, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Parameters

[out] dst

riscv_dsp_absdiff_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_absdiff_q31 (q31_t * src1, q31_t * src2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0, 0x7FFFFFFF].

  • If the input value is INT32_MIN (0x80000000), then the output value is INT32_MAX (0x7FFFFFFF).

riscv_dsp_absdiff_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_absdiff_q15 (q15_t * src1, q15_t * src2, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0, 0x7FFF].

  • If the input value is INT16_MIN (0x8000), then the output value is INT16_MAX (0x7FFF).

riscv_dsp_absdiff_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_absdiff_q7 (q7_t * src1, q7_t * src2, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the destination vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The range of output results is [0, 0x7F].

  • If the input value is INT8_MIN (0x80), then the output value is INT8_MAX (0x7F).

Complex Functions

Complex functions provide calculations for complex vectors.

In Andes DSP library, the elements of complex vectors must be arranged with interleaved real and imaginary parts. The memory layout should follow the pattern: [real, imaginary, real, imaginary, …​ , real, imaginary].

Complex Conjugate Functions

These functions compute the conjugation values of complex numbers in a source vector and store the results in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[2 * n] = src[2 * n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[2 * n + 1] = -src[2 * n + 1];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cconj_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cconj_f32 (const float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Example

Given a set of complex vectors containing three complex elements, such as {3 + 4i, 4 - 7i, -3 + 5i}, the complex conjugation is as follows:

//Complex vector is arranged with real and
//imaginary parts interleaved
#define size    3
float32_t src[2 * size] = {3.0, 4.0, 4.0, -7.0, -3.0, 5.0};
float32_t dst[2 * size];
riscv_dsp_cconj_f32 (src, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, Q31, and Q15 complex conjugate functions.

riscv_dsp_cconj_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cconj_f16 (const float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_cconj_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cconj_q31 (const q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The real and imaginary parts in complex vectors are both within the Q31 range.

  • If negating the input imaginary part where the value is INT32_MIN (0x80000000), the output imaginary part will be INT32_MAX (0x7FFFFFFF) after complex conjugation.

riscv_dsp_cconj_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cconj_q15 (const q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • The real and imaginary parts in complex vectors are both within the Q15 range.

  • If negating the input imaginary part where the value is INT16_MIN (0x8000), the output imaginary part will be INT16_MAX (0x7FFF) after complex conjugation.

Complex Dot Product Functions

These functions calculate the dot product of two complex vectors and store the results in a destination vector.

Andes DSP library provides two types of complex dot product functions.

The first type of complex dot product functions includes riscv_dsp_cdprod_f32, riscv_dsp_cdprod_f16, riscv_dsp_cdprod_q31, and riscv_dsp_cdprod_q15. Their behavior can be described as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{a = src1[2 * n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{b = src1[2 * n + 1];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{c = src2[2 * n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d = src2[2 * n + 1];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[2 * n] = a * c + b * d;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[2 * n + 1] = a * d - b * c;} \end{aligned} \]

The second type of complex dot product functions, named as complex dot product type 2 functions, includes riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_f32, riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_f16, riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_q31, and riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_q15. The behavior can be described as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{a = src1[2 * n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{b = src1[2 * n + 1];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{c = src2[2 * n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d = src2[2 * n + 1];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{real\_sum += a * c - b * d;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{image\_sum += a * d + b * c;} \end{aligned} \]

Details of each complex dot product functions are introduced in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cdprod_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cdprod_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size, float32_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector
Returns

None

Example

Given two sets of complex vectors, each containing three complex numbers, such as {3 + 4i, 4 - 7i, -3 + 5i} and {1 - 2i, 5 - 1i, -4 + 3i}, the complex dot production is as follows:

#define size    3
float32_t src1[2 * size] = {3, 4, 4, -7, -3, 5};
float32_t src2[2 * size] = {1, -2, 5, -1, -4, 3};
float32_t dst[2 * size];
riscv_dsp_cdprod_f32 (src1, src2, size, dst);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, Q31, and Q15 complex dot product functions.

riscv_dsp_cdprod_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cdprod_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, uint32_t size, float16_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_cdprod_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cdprod_q31 (const q31_t * src1, const q31_t * src2, uint32_t size, q31_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector
Returns

None

Note

The values written into the destination vector are in Q29 format.

riscv_dsp_cdprod_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cdprod_q15 (const q15_t * src1, const q15_t * src2, uint32_t size, q15_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector
Returns

None

Note

The values written into the destination vector are in Q13 format.

riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size, float32_t * rout, float32_t * iout)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector

[out] rout

Pointer to the real output

[out] iout

Pointer to the image output
Returns

None

Example

Given a set of complex vectors containing three complex numbers, such as {3 + 4i, 4 - 7i, -3 + 5i} and {1 - 2i, 5 - 1i, -4 + 3i}, the complex dot production of this function is as follows:

#define size    3
float32_t src1[2 * size] = {3, 4, 4, -7, -3, 5};
float32_t src2[2 * size] = {1, -2, 5, -1, -4, 3};
float32_t real_out, image_out;
riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_f32 (src1, src2, size, &real_out, &image_out);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, Q31, and Q15 complex dot product type 2 functions.

riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cdprod_typ2_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, uint32_t size, float16_t * rout, float16_t * iout)

[in] src2

Number of complex elements in a vector

[out] rout

Pointer to the real output

[out] iout

Pointer to the image output
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

[out] iout

Complex Magnitude Functions

These functions compute the magnitude of a complex vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, n < size; \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = \sqrt{src[2 * n]^2 + src[2 * n + 1]^2};} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cmag_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmag_f32 (const float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_cmag_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmag_f16 (const float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

riscv_dsp_cmag_hp_q15

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The values written into the destination vector are in Q14 format.

When compared with riscv_dsp_cmag_q15, this function delivers higher precision at the cost of slower performance.

Complex Magnitude Squared Functions

These functions compute the magnitude squared of complex numbers in a complex vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, n < size; \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src[2 * n]^2 + src[2 * n + 1]^2;} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cmag_sqr_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmag_sqr_f32 (const float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)

[out] dst

Returns

None

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Complex Multiply Complex Functions

These functions compute the multiplication of two complex vectors and store the results in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, n < size; \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{a = src1[2 * n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{b = src1[2 * n + 1];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{c = src2[2 * n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d = src2[2 * n + 1];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[2 * n] = a * c - b * d;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[2 * n + 1] = a * d + b * c;} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cmul_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmul_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Example

Given two sets of complex vectors each containing three complex numbers, such as [3 + 4i, 4 - 7i, -3 + 5i] and [1 - 2i, 5 - 1i, -4 + 3i], the multiplication of the two complex vectors is as follows:

#define size    3
float32_t src1[2 * size] = {3, 4, 4, -7, -3, 5};
float32_t src2[2 * size] = {1, -2, 5, -1, -4, 3};
float32_t dst[2 * size];
riscv_dsp_cmul_f32 (src1, src2, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31 and Q15 complex-multiply-complex functions.

riscv_dsp_cmul_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmul_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_cmul_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmul_f64 (const float64_t * src1, const float64_t * src2, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)

Pointer to the first input complex vector

[in] src2

[out] dst

None

[out] dst

The values written into the destination vector are in Q29 format.
