[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of complex elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The values written into the destination vector are in Q13 format.

Complex Multiply Real Functions

These functions compute the multiplication of a complex vector by a real vector and store the results in a destination complex vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, n < size; \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{r = real[n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[2 * n] = src[2 * n] * r;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[2 * n + 1] = src[2 * n + 1] * r;} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cmul_real_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmul_real_f32 (const float32_t * src, const float32_t * real, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[in] real

Pointer to the input real vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Example

Given a complex vector containing three elements, such as [3 + 4i, 4 - 7i, -3 + 5i], and a real vector containing three elements, such as [1, -3, 2], the multiplication of the two vectors is as follows:

#define size    3
float32_t src[2 * size] = {3, 4, 4, -7, -3, 5};
float32_t real[size] = {1, -3, 2};
float32_t dst[2 * size];
riscv_dsp_cmul_real_f32 (src, real, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, Q31, and Q15 complex-multiply-real functions.

riscv_dsp_cmul_real_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmul_real_f16 (const float16_t * src, const float16_t * real, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[in] real

Pointer to the input real vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_cmul_real_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmul_real_q31 (const q31_t * src, const q31_t * real, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[in] real

Pointer to the input real vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q31 range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF].

riscv_dsp_cmul_real_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmul_real_q15 (const q15_t * src, const q15_t * real, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex vector

[in] real

Pointer to the input real vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q15 range [0x8000, 0x7FFF].

Controller Functions

This section includes the following controller functions.

Clarke Transform Functions

These functions translate quantities from a three-phase system (a, b, and c axes) into a two-axis reference frame (alpha and beta axes), as illustrated in Clarke Transform.

Figure 1. Clarke Transform

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{array}{l} \mathtt{let} \ \mathtt{I_{\scriptscriptstyle{a}} + I_{\scriptscriptstyle{b}} + I_{\scriptscriptstyle{c}} = 0} \\ \mathtt{such \ that,} \\ \mathtt{isqrt3} = \mathtt{1 / \sqrt{3}}; \\ \mathtt{i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\alpha}}} = \mathtt{I_{\scriptscriptstyle{a}}}; \\ \mathtt{i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\beta}}} = \mathtt{{isqrt3} * I_{\scriptscriptstyle{a}}} + \mathtt{2} * \mathtt{{isqrt3} * I_{\scriptscriptstyle{b}}} \end{array} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point and Q31. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_clarke_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_clarke_f32 (float32_t a, float32_t b, float32_t * alpha, float32_t * beta)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] a

Quantity a of a three-phase system

[in] b

Quantity b of a three-phase system

[out] alpha

Pointer to the alpha axis of a two-phase reference frame

[out] beta

Pointer to the beta axis of a two-phase reference frame
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_clarke_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_clarke_q31 (q31_t a, q31_t b, q31_t * alpha, q31_t * beta)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] a

Quantity a of a three-phase system

[in] b

Quantity b of a three-phase system

[out] alpha

Pointer to the alpha axis of a two-phase reference frame

[out] beta

Pointer to the beta axis of a two-phase reference frame
Returns

None

Inverse Clarke Transform Functions

These functions translate a two-axis reference frame (alpha and beta axes) back to a three-phase system (a, b, and c axes).

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{array}{l} \mathtt{I_{\scriptscriptstyle{a}} = i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\alpha}};} \\ \mathtt{I_{\scriptscriptstyle{b}} = -0.5 * i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\alpha}} + 0.5 * \sqrt{3} * i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\beta}};} \end{array} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point and Q31. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_inv_clarke_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_inv_clarke_f32 (float32_t alpha, float32_t beta, float32_t * a, float32_t * b)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] alpha

Alpha axis of a two-phase reference frame

[in] beta

Beta axis of a two-phase reference frame

[out] a

Pointer to the quantity a of a three-phase system

[out] b

Pointer to the quantity b of a three-phase system
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_inv_clarke_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_inv_clarke_q31 (q31_t alpha, q31_t beta, q31_t * a, q31_t * b)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] alpha

Alpha axis of a two-phase reference frame

[in] beta

Beta axis of a two-phase reference frame

[out] a

Pointer to the quantity a of a three-phase system

[out] b

Pointer to the quantity b of a three-phase system
Returns

None

Park Transform Functions

These functions rotate an input two-phase coordinate (alpha and beta axes) into a rotor frame (a and b axes) by an angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\), as illustrated in Park Transform.

Figure 2. Park Transform

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{array}{l} \mathtt{Cosval = cos(\Theta)}; \quad \mathtt{Sinval = sin(\Theta)}; \\ \mathtt{i_{\scriptscriptstyle{a}}} = \mathtt{i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\alpha}} * Cosval + i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\beta}} * Sinval}; \\ \mathtt{i_{\scriptscriptstyle{b}}} = \mathtt{-i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\alpha}} * Sinval + i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\beta}} * Cosval} \end{array} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point and Q31. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_park_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_park_f32 (float32_t alpha, float32_t beta, float32_t * a, float32_t * b, float32_t sin, float32_t cos)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] alpha

Alpha phase of an input two-phase coordinate

[in] beta

Beta phase of an input two-phase coordinate

[out] a

Pointer to the a-axis of an output rotor frame

[out] b

Pointer to the b-axis of an output rotor frame

[in] sin

Sine value of the rotation angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\)

[in] cos

Cosine value of the rotation angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\)
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_park_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_park_q31 (q31_t alpha, q31_t beta, q31_t * a, q31_t * b, q31_t sin, q31_t cos)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] alpha

Alpha phase of an input two-phase coordinate

[in] beta

Beta phase of an input two-phase coordinate

[out] a

Pointer to the a-axis of an output rotor frame

[out] b

Pointer to the b-axis of an output rotor frame

[in] sin

Sine value of the rotation angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\)

[in] cos

Cosine value of the rotation angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\)
Returns

None

Inverse Park Transform Functions

These functions translate a rotor frame (a and b axes) back to a two-phase coordinate (alpha and beta axes) by rotating an angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\).

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{array}{l} \mathtt{i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\alpha}}} = \mathtt{i_{\scriptscriptstyle{a}} * Cosval - i_{\scriptscriptstyle{b}} * Sinval}; \\ \mathtt{i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\beta}}} = \mathtt{-i_{\scriptscriptstyle{\alpha}} * Sinval + i_{\scriptscriptstyle{b}} * Cosval} \end{array} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point and Q31. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_inv_park_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_inv_park_f32 (float32_t a, float32_t b, float32_t * alpha, float32_t * beta, float32_t sin, float32_t cos)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] a

a-axis of an input rotor frame

[in] b

b-axis of an input rotor frame

[out] alpha

Pointer to the alpha phase of an output two-phase coordinate

[out] beta

Pointer to the beta phase of an output two-phase coordinate

[in] sin

Sine value of the rotation angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\)

[in] cos

Cosine value of the rotation angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\)
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_inv_park_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_inv_park_q31 (q31_t a, q31_t b, q31_t * alpha, q31_t * beta, q31_t sin, q31_t cos)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] a

a-axis of an input rotor frame

[in] b

b-axis of an input rotor frame

[out] alpha

Pointer to the alpha phase of an output two-phase coordinate

[out] beta

Pointer to the beta phase of an output two-phase coordinate

[in] sin

Sine value of the rotation angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\)

[in] cos

Cosine value of the rotation angle \(\mathtt{\Theta}\)
Returns

None

Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) Controller Functions

These functions provide a continuous feedback mechanism to periodically control output errors based on the inputs. State of PID Controller illustrates the state of the PID controller.

Figure 3. State of PID Controller

In the controller process, when current data is input at each time step, the behavior is as follows:

\[ \begin{array}{l} \mathtt{output = Kp * current\_data + Ki * state0 + Kd * state1 + state2;} \\ \mathtt{state2 = output;} \\ \mathtt{state1 = state0;} \\ \mathtt{state0 = current\_data;} \end{array} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_init_pid_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_init_pid_f32 (riscv_dsp_pid_f32_t * instance, int32_t set)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_pid_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point PID function, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    float32_t gain1;
    float32_t gain2;
    float32_t gain3;
    float32_t state[3];
    float32_t Kp;
    float32_t Ki;
    float32_t Kd;
} riscv_dsp_pid_f32_t;

where:

gain1

Represents Kp + Ki + Kd

gain2

Represents -Kp - 2Kd

gain3

Represents Kd

state[3]

State buffer

Kp

Proportional value

Ki

Integral value

Kd

Derivative value

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] set

If its value is zero, it does nothing; otherwise, it clears the state buffer.
Returns

None

Example

When the gain1, gain2, gain3, and state[3] parameters are managed by the controller, manually input Kp, Ki, and Kd. For example:

riscv_dsp_pid_f32_t instance;
instance.Kp = 0.02F;
instance.Ki = 0.03F;
instance.Kd = 0.014F;

//initialize controller
riscv_dsp_init_pid_f32 (&instance, 1);

//Begin controller
while (1)
{
    float32_t output;
    float32_t input = ... read data from input port ...
    output = riscv_dsp_pid_f32 (&instance, input);
    ...
}

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 PID initialization and PID functions.

Note

Call this function to initialize the controller before executing the riscv_dsp_pid_f32 function.

riscv_dsp_pid_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_pid_f32 (riscv_dsp_pid_f32_t * instance, float32_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_pid_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point PID function, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    float32_t gain1;
    float32_t gain2;
    float32_t gain3;
    float32_t state[3];
    float32_t Kp;
    float32_t Ki;
    float32_t Kd;
} riscv_dsp_pid_f32_t;

where:

gain1

Represents Kp + Ki + Kd

gain2

Represents -Kp - 2Kd

gain3

Represents Kd

state[3]

State buffer

Kp

Proportional value

Ki

Integral value

Kd

Derivative value

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Current data
Returns

The output of the controller

Note

Call the riscv_dsp_init_pid_f32 function to initialize the controller, then execute this riscv_dsp_pid_f32 function to process the loop and adjust the controller’s outputs based on the current data. See riscv_dsp_init_pid_f32 for an example.

riscv_dsp_init_pid_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_init_pid_q31 (riscv_dsp_pid_q31_t * instance, int32_t set)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_pid_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 PID function, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    q31_t gain1;
    q31_t gain2;
    q31_t gain3;
    q31_t state[3];
    q31_t Kp;
    q31_t Ki;
    q31_t Kd;
} riscv_dsp_pid_q31_t;

where:

gain1

Represents Kp + Ki + Kd

gain2

Represents -Kp - 2Kd

gain3

Represents Kd

state[3]

State buffer

Kp

Proportional value

Ki

Integral value

Kd

Derivative value

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] set

If its value is zero, it does nothing; otherwise, it clears the state buffer.
Returns

None

Note

  • Call this function to initialize the controller before executing the riscv_dsp_pid_q31 function.

  • When the gain1, gain2, gain3, and state[3] parameters are managed by the controller, manually input Kp, Ki, and Kd.

riscv_dsp_pid_q31

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_pid_q31 (riscv_dsp_pid_q31_t * instance, q31_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_pid_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 PID function, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    q31_t gain1;
    q31_t gain2;
    q31_t gain3;
    q31_t state[3];
    q31_t Kp;
    q31_t Ki;
    q31_t Kd;
} riscv_dsp_pid_q31_t;

where:

gain1

Represents Kp + Ki + Kd

gain2

Represents -Kp - 2Kd

gain3

Represents Kd

state[3]

State buffer

Kp

Proportional value

Ki

Integral value

Kd

Derivative value

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Current data
Returns

The output of the controller

Note

Call the riscv_dsp_init_pid_q31 function to initialize the controller, then, execute this riscv_dsp_pid_q31 function to process the loop and adjust the controller’s outputs based on the current data. See riscv_dsp_init_pid_f32 for an example.

riscv_dsp_init_pid_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_init_pid_q15 (riscv_dsp_pid_q15_t * instance, int32_t set)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_pid_ q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 PID function, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    q15_t gain1;
    q15_t gain2;
    q15_t gain3;
    q15_t state[3];
    q15_t Kp;
     q15_t Ki;
    q15_t Kd;
} riscv_dsp_pid_ q15_t;

where:

gain1

Represents Kp + Ki + Kd

gain2

Represents -Kp - 2Kd

gain3

Represents Kd

state[3]

State buffer

Kp

Proportional value

Ki

Integral value

Kd

Derivative value

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] set

If its value is zero, it does nothing; otherwise, it clears the state buffer.
Returns

None

Note

  • Call this function to initialize the controller before executing the riscv_dsp_pid_q15 function.

  • When the gain1, gain2, gain3, and state[3] parameters are managed by the controller, manually input Kp, Ki, and Kd.

riscv_dsp_pid_q15

Declaration
q15_t riscv_dsp_pid_q15 (riscv_dsp_pid_q15_t * instance, q15_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_pid_ q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 PID function, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    q15_t gain1;
    q15_t gain2;
    q15_t gain3;
    q15_t state[3];
    q15_t Kp;
    q15_t Ki;
    q15_t Kd;
} riscv_dsp_pid_ q15_t;

where:

gain1

Represents Kp + Ki + Kd

gain2

Represents -Kp - 2Kd

gain3

Represents Kd

state[3]

State buffer

Kp

Proportional value

Ki

Integral value

Kd

Derivative value

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Returns

The output of the controller

Note

Call the riscv_dsp_init_pid_q15 function to initialize the controller, then, execute this riscv_dsp_pid_q15 function to process the loop and adjust the controller’s outputs based on the current data. See riscv_dsp_init_pid_f32 for an example.

Filtering Functions

This section includes the following filtering functions.

Biquadratic Cascade Filters Direct Form I (DF1) Functions

These functions implement a biquadratic filter in direct form I (DF1), where each stage is implemented as an individual biquadratic cascade filter, as described by the following equation:

\[ \mathtt{dst[n] = b0 * src[n] + b1 * src[n-1] + b2 * src[n-2] + a1 * dst[n-1] + a2 * dst[n-2]} ; \]

The equation uses five coefficients and four state variables per stage. The coefficients (\(\mathtt{b0}\), \(\mathtt{b1}\), and \(\mathtt{b2}\)) define the zeros, while the coefficients \(\mathtt{a1}\) and \(\mathtt{a2}\) define the positions of the poles.

Instance structures store information such as the stages and coefficients, and save the state in each stage. Before using a biquadratic cascade filter function, ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures first.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and 32x64 Q31, to meet high precision requirements. These functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f32 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f32_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
4 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define nstage    3
#define size      6
float32_t state[4 * nstage] = {0.0};
float32_t coeff[5 * nstage] = {0.40, 0.10, 0.24, -0.40, -0.34, 0.20, 0.06, 0.28, -0.04, -0.20, 0.08, 0.40, 0.60, -1.00, -0.14};
float32_t src[size] = {1.0, 0.5, 0.4, -0.1, -0.1, 0.3};
float32_t dst[size];
riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f32_t instance = {nstage, state, coeff};
riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f32 (&instance, src, dst, size);

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f16 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f16_t * instance, float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f16_t

Instance structure of the F16 biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    float16_t * state;
    float16_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df1_f16_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
4 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * coeff;
    int8_t shift;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
4 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage

shift

Shift bits

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define shift     0
#define nstage    3
#define size      6
q31_t state_q31[4 * nstage] = {0} ;
q31_t coeff_q31[5 * nstage], src_q31[size], dst_q31[size];
riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31_t instance_q31 = {nstage, state_q31, coeff_q31, shift};
float32_t coeff_f32[5 * nstage] = {0.40, 0.10, 0.24, -0.40, -0.34, 0.20, 0.06, 0.28, -0.04, -0.20, 0.08, 0.40, 0.60, -1.00, -0.14};
float32_t src_f32[size] = {1.0, 0.5, 0.4, -0.1, -0.1, 0.3};
riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q31 (coeff_f32, coeff_q31, 5 * nstage);
riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q31 (src_f32, src_q31, size);
riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31 (&instance_q31, src_q31, dst_q31, size);

This example of the Q31 biquadratic cascade filter function uses the riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q31 function to convert the F32 vector to Q31. You can reference this example for the Q15 biquadratic cascade filter function as well, but be sure to replace riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q31 with riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q15.

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_fast_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df1_fast_q31 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * coeff;
    int8_t shift;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
4 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage

shift

Shift bits

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

When compared with riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31, this function delivers higher performance with lower precision by using a 32-bit accumulator.

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * coeff;
    int8_t shift;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
4 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage or 6 * nstage when using the DSP extension.

shift

Shift bits

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

The coefficient vector stores coefficients in the order {\(\mathtt{b0}\), \(\mathtt{b1}\), \(\mathtt{b2}\), \(\mathtt{a1}\), \(\mathtt{a2}\), \(\mathtt{...}\)}. The first five elements are for the first stage, the next five are for the second stage, and so on.

When using the DSP extension, the order changes to {\(\mathtt{b0}\), \(\mathtt{0}\), \(\mathtt{b1}\), \(\mathtt{b2}\), \(\mathtt{a1}\), \(\mathtt{a2}\), \(\mathtt{...}\)}, with a zero (0) element inserted between b0 and b1 for SIMD load/store instructions.

In this case, the first six elements correspond to the first stage, the next six to the second stage, and so on.

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_fast_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df1_fast_q15 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * coeff;
    int8_t shift;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
4 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage or 6 * nstage when using the DSP extension.

shift

Shift bits

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

  • The coefficient vector stores coefficients in the order {\(\mathtt{b0}\), \(\mathtt{b1}\), \(\mathtt{b2}\), \(\mathtt{a1}\), \(\mathtt{a2}\), \(\mathtt{...}\)}. The first five elements are for the first stage, the next five are for the second stage, and so on.

    When using the DSP extension, the order changes to {\(\mathtt{b0}\), \(\mathtt{0}\), \(\mathtt{b1}\), \(\mathtt{b2}\), \(\mathtt{a1}\), \(\mathtt{a2}\), \(\mathtt{...}\)}, with a zero (0) element inserted between b0 and b1 for SIMD load/store instructions.

    In this case, the first six elements correspond to the first stage, the next six to the second stage, and so on.

  • When compared with riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q15, this function delivers higher performance.

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_32x64_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df1_32x64_q31 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df1_32x64_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_df1_32x64_q31_t

Instance structure of the 32x64 Q31 biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    q63_t * state;
    q31_t * coeff;
    int8_t shift;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df1_32x64_q31_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
4 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage

shift

Shift bits

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function stores and updates intermediate results using a 64-bit state buffer to calculate accumulated values, achieving higher accuracy compared to the riscv_dsp_bq_df1_q31 function.

Biquadratic Cascade Filters Direct Form II Transposed (DF2T) Functions

These functions implement a biquadratic filter in direct form II (DF2), where each stage is implemented as an individual transposed biquadratic cascade filter, as described by the following equation:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{out[n] = b0 * in[n] + d0;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d0 = b1 * in[n] + a1 * out[n] + d1;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d1 = b2 * in[n] + a2 * out[n];} \end{aligned} \]

In the equation, five coefficients (\(\mathtt{b0}\), \(\mathtt{b1}\), \(\mathtt{b2}\), \(\mathtt{a1}\), and \(\mathtt{a2}\)) and two state variables (\(\mathtt{d0}\) and \(\mathtt{d1}\)) are used per stage. After completing each stage, the two state variables are saved into a state vector.

Additionally, these functions implement a direct form II transposed biquadratic cascade filter for stereo (2-channel) signals, as described by the following equation:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n+=2)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{out[n] = b0 * in[n] + d00;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{out[n + 1] = b0 * in[n + 1] + d01;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d00 = b1 * in[n] + a1 * out[n] + d10;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d01 = b1 * in[n + 1] + a1 * out[n + 1] + d11;} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d10 = b2 * in[n] + a2 * out[n];} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{d11 = b2 * in[n + 1] + a2 * out[n + 1];} \end{aligned} \]

In the equation, five coefficients (\(\mathtt{b0}\), \(\mathtt{b1}\), \(\mathtt{b2}\), \(\mathtt{a1}\), and \(\mathtt{a2}\)) and four state variables (\(\mathtt{d00}\), \(\mathtt{d01}\), \(\mathtt{d10}\), and \(\mathtt{d11}\)) are used per stage. After completing each stage, the four state variables are saved into a state vector.

Instance structures store information such as the stages and coefficients, and save the state in each stage. Before using a biquadratic cascade filter function, ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures first.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f32 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f32_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
2 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define nstage    3
#define size      6
float32_t state[2 * nstage] = {0.0};
float32_t coeff[5 * nstage] = {0.40, 0.10, 0.24, -0.40, -0.34, 0.20, 0.06, 0.28, -0.04, -0.20, 0.08, 0.40, 0.60, -1.00, -0.14};
float32_t src[size] = {1, 0.5, 0.4, -0.1, -0.1, 0.3};
float32_t dst[size];
riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f32_t instance = {nstage, state, coeff};
riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f32 (&instance, src, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16 and F64 direct form II transposed biquadratic cascade filter functions.

riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f16 (const riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f16_t * instance, float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

    uint32_t nstage;
    float16_t * state;
    float16_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_bq_df2T_f16_t;

where:

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
2 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

[out] dst

For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_bq_stereo_df2T_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_bq_stereo_df2T_f32 (const riscv_dsp_bq_stereo_df2T_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size);
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_bq_stereo_df2T_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 biquadratic cascade filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_bq_stereo_df2T_f32_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is
4 * nstage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is
5 * nstage

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define nstage    3
#define size      1024
float32_t state[4 * nstage] = {0.0};
float32_t coeff[5 * nstage] = {0.40, 0.10, 0.24, -0.40, -0.34, 0.20, 0.06, 0.28, -0.04, -0.20, 0.08, 0.40, 0.60, -1.00, -0.14};
float32_t src[size * 2] = {...};
float32_t dst[size * 2];
riscv_dsp_bq_stereo_df2T_f32_t instance = {nstage, state, coeff};
riscv_dsp_bq_stereo_df2T_f32 (&instance, src, dst, size);

Convolution Functions

These functions combine two signals into one signal mathematically. The convolution equation can be presented as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ dst[n] = \sum_{k=0}^{len1} (src1[k] * src2[n - k]) } \]

where the size of \(\mathtt{src1[n]}\) is \(\mathtt{len1}\), the size of \(\mathtt{src2[n]}\) is \(\mathtt{len2}\), and the size of \(\mathtt{dst[n]}\) is \(\mathtt{len1 + len2 - 1}\).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_conv_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_conv_f32 (float32_t * src1, uint32_t len1, float32_t * src2, uint32_t len2, float32_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] len1

Length of the first input vector

[in] scr2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] len2

Length of the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

None

Example
#define len1    6
#define len2    4
float32_t src1[len1] = {0.3, 0.2, -0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.2};
float32_t src2[len2] = {-0.1, 0.3, 0.2, -0.2};
float32_t dst[len1 + len2 - 1];
riscv_dsp_conv_f32 (src1, len1, src2, len2, dst);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31, Q15, and Q7 convolution functions.

riscv_dsp_conv_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_conv_q31 (q31_t * src1, uint32_t len1, q31_t * src2, uint32_t len2, q31_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] len1

Length of the first input vector

[in] scr2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] len2

Length of the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_conv_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_conv_q15 (q15_t * src1, uint32_t len1, q15_t * src2, uint32_t len2, q15_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] len1

Length of the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] len2

Length of the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_conv_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_conv_q7 (q7_t * src1, uint32_t len1, q7_t * src2, uint32_t len2, q7_t * dst)

Parameters are described as follows:

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

Length of the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] len2

Length of the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

None

Partial Convolution Functions

Given a starting index and a specified size, partial convolution functions perform convolution on a portion of two signals. The result is stored in the destination vector within the range
\(\mathtt{[startindex \, , \, \dots \, , \, startindex + size - 1 ]}\). Thus, if the partial convolution result falls outside the range \(\mathtt{[0 \, , \, \dots \, , \, len1 + len2 - 2]}\), the function will return -1 to indicate an argument error.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_conv_partial_f32

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_conv_partial_f32 (float32_t * src1, uint32_t len1, float32_t * src2, uint32_t len2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t startindex, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] len1

Length of the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] len2

Length of the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] startindex

Starting index of the partial convolution

[in] size

Length of the partial convolution
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if partial convolution fails

Example
#define len1    6
#define len2    4
float32_t src1[len1] = {0.3, 0.2, -0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.2};
float32_t src2[len2] = {-0.1, 0.3, 0.2, -0.2};
float32_t dst[len1 + len2 - 1];
riscv_dsp_conv_partial_f32 (src1, len1, src2, len2, dst, 3, 4);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31, Q15, and Q7 partial convolution functions.

riscv_dsp_conv_partial_q31

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_conv_partial_q31 (q31_t * src1, uint32_t len1, q31_t * src2, uint32_t len2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t startindex, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] len1

Length of the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] len2

Length of the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] startindex

Starting index of the partial convolution

[in] size

Length of the partial convolution
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if partial convolution fails

Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if partial convolution fails

Correlation Functions

These functions use two signals to form another signal (also called cross-correlation) mathematically. The mathematical operations of correlation functions are similar to those of convolution functions and can be presented as follows:

\[ \mathtt{dst[n] = \sum_{k=0}^{len1} \left( src1[k] * src2[k - n] \right)} \]

where \(\mathtt{src1}\) and \(\mathtt{src2}\) are input vectors, and their lengths are \(\mathtt{len1}\) and \(\mathtt{len2}\) separately; \(\mathtt{dst}\) is the output vector and its size is \(\mathtt{2 * max (len1, \, len2) - 1}\).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_corr_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_corr_f32 (float32_t * src1, uint32_t len1, float32_t * src2, uint32_t len2, float32_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] len1

Length of the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] len2

Length of the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

None

Example
#define len1    7
#define len2    5
float32_t src1[len1] = {0.3, 0.2, -0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.2, -0.1};
float32_t src2[len2] = {-0.1, 0.3, 0.2, -0.2, -0.2};
float32_t dst[2 * len1 - 1];
riscv_dsp_conv_f32 (src1, len1, src2, len2, dst);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, Q15, and Q7 correlation functions.

riscv_dsp_corr_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_corr_f16 (float16_t * src1, uint32_t len1, float16_t * src2, uint32_t len2, float16_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] len1

Length of the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] len2

Length of the second input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_corr_f64

[in] len2

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

None

Finite Impulse Response (FIR) Filter Functions

These functions can be presented by the following equation:

\[ \mathtt{dst[n] = \sum_{k=0}^{Size} \left( b[k] * src[n-k] \right)} \]

where \(\mathtt{b[k]}\) is the filter coefficient and \(\mathtt{Size}\) is the number of filter coefficients.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7.

Ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures before using the FIR filter functions. These functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_fir_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_fir_f32 (const riscv_dsp_fir_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_fir_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_fir_f32_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define coeff_size    4
#define size          6
float32_t state[coeff_size + size - 1];
float32_t coeff[coeff_size] = {0.3, -0.1, 0.4, 0.5};
riscv_dsp_fir_f32_t instance = {coeff_size, state, coeff};
float32_t src[size] = {0.1, -0.2, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, 0.1};
float32_t dst[size];
riscv_dsp_fir_f32 (&instance, src, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, fast_Q31, Q15, fast_Q15, and Q7 FIR filter functions.

riscv_dsp_fir_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_fir_f16 (const riscv_dsp_fir_f16_t * instance, float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_fir_f16_t

Instance structure of the F16 FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    float16_t * state;
    float16_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_fir_f16_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_fir_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_fir_f64 (const riscv_dsp_fir_f64_t * instance, float64_t * src, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)

Parameter Description

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    float64_t * state;
    float64_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_fir_f64_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

[in] instance

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples

riscv_dsp_fir_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_fir_q31 (const riscv_dsp_fir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_fir_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_fir_q31_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

  • This function represents both coefficients and state variables in Q31 format and yields the multiplication results in Q2.62 format. It right-shifts these results by 31 bits, saturates them to Q31 format, and saves them into the buffer.

    To avoid overflow, scale down the input signal by log2(coeff_size) bits before calling this function.

  • When compared with riscv_dsp_fir_fast_q31, this function delivers higher precision and a smaller code size.

riscv_dsp_fir_fast_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_fir_fast_q31 (const riscv_dsp_fir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_fir_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_fir_q31_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

  • This function represents both coefficients and state variables in Q31 format and yields the multiplication results in Q1.31 format. It left-shifts these results by 1 bits, saturates them to Q31 format, and saves them into the buffer.

    To avoid overflow, scale down the input signal by log2(coeff_size) bits before calling this function.

  • When compared with riscv_dsp_fir_q31, this function delivers higher performance with lower precision and a larger code size.

riscv_dsp_fir_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_fir_q15 (const riscv_dsp_fir_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_fir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_fir_q15_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

  • This function represents both coefficients and state variables in Q15 format and yields the multiplication results in Q30 format. It uses a 64-bit accumulator to accumulate the results in Q34.30 format, and then truncates them to Q34.15 format by discarding the lower 15 bits. Finally, it saturates the outputs to produce a result in Q1.15 format.

  • When compared with riscv_dsp_fir_fast_q15, this function delivers higher precision and a smaller code size.

riscv_dsp_fir_fast_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_fir_fast_q15 (const riscv_dsp_fir_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_fir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_fir_q15_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

  • This function represents both coefficients and state variables in Q15 format and yields the multiplication results in Q30 format. It uses a 32-bit accumulator to accumulate the results in Q2.30 format, and then saturates them to yield a result in Q1.15 format. Finally, it saturates the outputs to produce a result in Q1.15 format.

  • When compared with riscv_dsp_fir_q15, this function delivers higher performance with lower precision and a larger code size.

riscv_dsp_fir_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_fir_q7 (const riscv_dsp_fir_q7_t * instance, q7_t * src, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_fir_q7_t

Instance structure of the Q7 FIR filter. defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q7_t * state;
    q7_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_fir_q7_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function takes both inputs in Q7 format, and it yields the multiplication results in Q14 format. It uses a 32-bit accumulator to accumulate the intermediate results in Q18.14 format, and then truncate them to Q18.7 format by discarding the lower 7 bits. Finally, it saturates the outputs to produce a result in Q1.7 format.

Decimator FIR Filter Functions

These functions implement FIR filters with decimation by an integer factor \(\mathtt{M}\). They can be presented by the following equation:

\[ \mathtt{dst[n] = \sum_{k=0}^{Size} \left( b[k] * src[n - k] \right)} \]

where \(\mathtt{b[k]}\) is the filter coefficient, \(\mathtt{src}\) is the input data of the length \(\mathtt{Size}\), and \(\mathtt{dst}\) is the output data of the length \(\mathtt{Size/M}\). Additionally, \(\mathtt{Size}\) must be a multiple of the decimation factor M so that the number of output samples can be an integer.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15.

Ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures before using the decimation FIR filter functions. The functions and their instance structures are described in the subsection below.

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dcmfir_f32 (const riscv_dsp_dcmfir_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point decimation FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t M;
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    float32_t * coeff;
    float32_t * state;
} riscv_dsp_dcmfir_f32_t;

where:

M

Decimation factor

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example

Given an input size of 24, a decimation factor M of 4, and a filter coefficient size of 6, set the instance of the decimation FIR filter as follows:

#define size          24
#define M             4
#define coeff_size    6
float32_t coeff[coeff_size] = {...};
float32_t state[coeff_size + size - 1];
riscv_dsp_dcmfir_f32_t instance = {M, coeff_size, coeff, state};
float32_t src[size] = {0.1, -0.2, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, 0.1, ...};
float32_t dst[size / M];
riscv_dsp_dcmfir_f32 (&instance, src, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 decimation FIR filter functions.

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31 (const riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 decimation FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t M;
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q31_t * coeff;
    q31_t * state;
} riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31_t;

where:

M

Decimation factor

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function represents both coefficients and state variables in Q31 format. It uses a 64-bit accumulator to perform multiply-accumulate operations with saturation, yielding results in Q1.62 format. After completing all operations, it saturates the results to Q31 format.

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_fast_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dcmfir_fast_q31 (const riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 decimation FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t M;
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q31_t * coeff;
    q31_t * state;
} riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31_t;

where:

M

Decimation factor

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

  • This function represents both coefficients and state variables in Q31 format. It uses a 32-bit accumulator to perform multiply-accumulate operations and truncates the results to Q2.30 format.

    To avoid overflow, scale down the input signal by log2(coeff_size) bits before calling this function.

    After completing all operations, it saturates the results and converts them to Q1.31 format.

  • When compared with riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q31, this function delivers higher performance with lower precision.

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15 (const riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 decimation FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t M;
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q15_t * coeff;
    q15_t * state;
} riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15_t;

where:

M

Decimation factor

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function represents both coefficients and state variables in Q15 format. It uses a 64-bit accumulator to perform multiply-accumulate operations with saturation, yielding results in Q33.30 format. After completing all operations, it saturates the results to Q15 format.

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_fast_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dcmfir_fast_q15 (const riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 decimation FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t M;
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q15_t * coeff;
    q15_t * state;
} riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15_t;

where:

M

Decimation factor

coeff_size

Number of coefficients

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

  • This function represents both coefficients and state variables in Q15 format. It uses a 32-bit accumulator to perform multiply-accumulate operations with saturation, yielding results in Q2.30 format. If the accumulator result overflows, it wraps around and distorts the results.

    To avoid overflow, scale down the input signal by log2(coeff_size) bits before calling this function.

    After completing all operations, this function truncates the results to Q2.15 format and saturates them to yield the final Q1.15 results.

  • When compared with riscv_dsp_dcmfir_q15, this function delivers higher performance.

Lattice FIR Filter Functions

These functions can be represented by the following equations:

\[ \begin{aligned} \mathtt{y_{\scriptscriptstyle{0}}[n]} & = \mathtt{u_{\scriptscriptstyle{0}}[n]} = \mathtt{x[n]} \\ \mathtt{y_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}}[n]} & = \mathtt{y_{\scriptscriptstyle{{z-1}}}[n]} + \mathtt{k_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}} u_{\scriptscriptstyle{{z-1}}}[n-1]} \\ \mathtt{u_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}}[n]} & = \mathtt{k_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}} y_{\scriptscriptstyle{{z-1}}}[n]} + \mathtt{u_{\scriptscriptstyle{{z-1}}}[n-1]} \end{aligned} \]

where \(\mathtt{x}\) is the input, \(\mathtt{y}\) is the output, \(\mathtt{u}\) represents the state of previous inputs, \(\mathtt{0 \leq z < M}\) (with \(\mathtt{M}\) as the stage number), and \(\mathtt{k_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}}}\) denotes the reflection coefficients.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15.

Ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures before using the lattice FIR filter functions. The functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_lfir_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_lfir_f32 (const riscv_dsp_lfir_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_lfir_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point lattice FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t stage;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_lfir_f32_t;

where:

stage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is stage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is stage

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example

Given a filter length of 6 and an input size of 8, set the instance of the lattice FIR filter as follows:

#define M       6
#define size    8
float32_t state[M];
float32_t coeff[M] = {...};
float32_t src[size] = {...};
float32_t dst[size];
riscv_dsp_lfir_f32_t instance = {M, state, coeff};
riscv_dsp_lfir_f32 (&instance, src, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 lattice FIR filter functions.

riscv_dsp_lfir_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_lfir_q31 (const riscv_dsp_lfir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

typedef struct {
    uint32_t stage;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_lfir_q31_t;

where:

stage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is stage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is stage

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

None
