Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_lfir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 lattice FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t stage;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * coeff;
} riscv_dsp_lfir_q15_t;

where:

stage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is stage

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is stage

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Lattice Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) Filter Functions

These functions can be represented as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} \mathtt{y_{\scriptscriptstyle{0}}[n]} & = \mathtt{x[n]} \\ \mathtt{y_{\scriptscriptstyle{z-1}}[n]} & = \mathtt{y_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}}[n] - k_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}} * u_{\scriptscriptstyle{z-1}}[n-1]} \\ \mathtt{u_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}}[n]} & = \mathtt{k_{\scriptscriptstyle{z}}} * \mathtt{y_{\scriptscriptstyle{{z-1}}}[n]} + \mathtt{u_{\scriptscriptstyle{z-1}}[n-1]} \\ \mathtt{w[n]} & = \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{N}} * u_{\scriptscriptstyle{N}}[n] + v_{\scriptscriptstyle{N-1}} * u_{\scriptscriptstyle{N-1}}[n] + \dots + v_{\scriptscriptstyle{0}} * u_{\scriptscriptstyle{0}}[n]} \end{aligned} \]

where \(\mathtt{N}\) is the number of states and \(\mathtt{z = N \, , \, N - 1 \, , \, \dots \, , \, 1}\), coefficients \(\mathtt{k = {\{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{N}} \, , \, r_{\scriptscriptstyle{N-1}} \, , \, \dots \, , \, r_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}}}\}\), \(\mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{N}}}\) is the ladder coefficients, and \(\mathtt{u}\) is the state.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15.

Ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures before using the lattice IIR filter functions. The functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_liir_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_liir_f32 (const riscv_dsp_liir_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_liir_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point lattice IIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * rcoeff;
    float32_t * lcoeff;
} riscv_dsp_liir_f32_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is nstage + size

rcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed reflection coefficient vector whose size is nstage

lcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed ladder coefficient vector whose size is nstage + 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define size      8
#define nstage    6
float32_t state[nstage + size];
float32_t rcoeff[nstage] = {...};
float32_t lcoeff[nstage + 1] = {...};
riscv_dsp_liir_f32_t instance = {nstage, state, rcoeff, lcoeff};
float32_t src[size] = {...};
float32_t dst[size];
riscv_dsp_liir_f32 (&instance, src, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31, fast_Q31, Q15, and fast_Q15 lattice IIR filter functions.

riscv_dsp_liir_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_liir_q31 (const riscv_dsp_liir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_liir_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 lattice IIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
 uint32_t nstage;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * rcoeff;
    q31_t * lcoeff;
} riscv_dsp_liir_q31_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is nstage + size

rcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed reflection coefficient vector whose size is nstage

lcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed ladder coefficient vector whose size is nstage + 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

When compared with riscv_dsp_liir_fast_q31, this function delivers a smaller code size with lower performance, while maintaining the same output accuracy.

riscv_dsp_liir_fast_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_liir_fast_q31 (const riscv_dsp_liir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_liir_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 lattice IIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * rcoeff;
    q31_t * lcoeff;
} riscv_dsp_liir_q31_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is nstage + size

rcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed reflection coefficient vector whose size is nstage

lcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed ladder coefficient vector whose size is nstage + 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples whose size must be a multiple of 2
Returns

None

Note

When compared with riscv_dsp_liir_q31, this function delivers higher performance with a larger code size, while maintaining the same output accuracy.

To avoid overflow, scale down the reflection coefficient by 2.

riscv_dsp_liir_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_liir_q15 (const riscv_dsp_liir_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_liir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 lattice IIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * rcoeff;
    q15_t * lcoeff;
} riscv_dsp_liir_q15_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is nstage + size

rcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed reflection coefficient vector whose size is nstage

lcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed ladder coefficient vector whose size is nstage + 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

When compared with riscv_dsp_liir_fast_q15, this function delivers a smaller code size with lower performance, while maintaining the same output accuracy.

riscv_dsp_liir_fast_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_liir_fast_q15 (const riscv_dsp_liir_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_liir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 lattice IIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t nstage;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * rcoeff;
    q15_t * lcoeff;
} riscv_dsp_liir_q15_t;

where:

nstage

Number of filter stages

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is nstage + size

rcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed reflection coefficient vector whose size is nstage

lcoeff

Pointer to the time reversed ladder coefficient vector whose size is nstage + 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples whose size must be a multiple of 2
Returns

None

Note

When compared with riscv_dsp_liir_q15, this function delivers higher performance with a larger code size, while maintaining the same output accuracy.

Least Mean Square (LMS) Filters Functions

These functions are adaptive filters that perform the following equations to update coefficients and minimize the mean square error:

\[ \begin{aligned} \mathtt{y[n]} & = \mathtt{h[0] * x[n] + h[1] * x[n - 1] + \dots + h[L - 1] * y[n - L + 1]} ;\\ \mathtt{e[n]} & = \mathtt{d[n] - y[n]} ;\\ \mathtt{h[k]} & = \mathtt{h[k - 1] + \mu * e[n] * x[n - k]} ; \end{aligned} \]

where:

  • y is the output vector

  • h is the coefficients vector

  • x is the input vector

  • L is the filter order

  • e is the error vector

  • d is the desired vector

  • \(\mathtt{\mu}\) is the step size, which can adjust coefficients

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15.

Ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures before using the LMS filter functions. The functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_lms_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_lms_f32 (const riscv_dsp_lms_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * ref, float32_t * dst, float32_t * err, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_lms_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point LMS filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * coeff;
    float32_t mu;
} riscv_dsp_lms_f32_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

mu

Step size that can adjust coefficients

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] ref

Pointer to the desired vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[out] err

Pointer to the error vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define coeff_size    5
#define size          6
#define mu            0.05
float32_t state[coeff_size + size - 1] = {0.0};
float32_t coeff[coeff_size] = {0.40, 0.10, 0.24, -0.40, -0.34};
float32_t src[size] = {1.0, 0.5, 0.4, -0.1, -0.1, 0.3};
float32_t ref[size] = {0.1, 0.2, -0.1, -0.02, -0.1, 0.2};
float32_t err[size];
float32_t dst[size];

riscv_dsp_lms_f32_t instance = {coeff_size, state, coeff, mu};
riscv_dsp_lms_f32 (&instance, src, ref, dst, err, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 LMS filter functions.

riscv_dsp_lms_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_lms_q31 (const riscv_dsp_lms_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * ref, q31_t * dst, q31_t * err, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_lms_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 LMS filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * coeff;
    q31_t mu;
    q31_t shift;
} riscv_dsp_lms_q31_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

mu

Step size that can adjust coefficients

shift

Number of coefficient bits to be shifted

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] ref

Pointer to the desired vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[out] err

Pointer to the error vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_lms_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_lms_q15 (const riscv_dsp_lms_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * ref, q15_t * dst, q15_t * err, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_lms_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 LMS filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * coeff;
    q15_t mu;
    q15_t shift;
} riscv_dsp_lms_q15_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

mu

Step size that can adjust coefficients

shift

Number of coefficient bits to be shifted

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] ref

Pointer to the desired vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[out] err

Pointer to the error vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Normalized LMS (NLMS) Filter Functions

These functions are extensions of LMS filter functions. They can be represented by the following equations:

\[ \begin{aligned} \mathtt{y[n]} & = \mathtt{h[0] * x[n] + h[1] * x[n - 1] + \dots + h[L - 1] * y[n - L + 1]} ;\\ \mathtt{e[n]} & = \mathtt{d[n] - y[n]} ;\\ \mathtt{\mu[n]} & = \mathtt{1 / x[n]^2} ;\\ \mathtt{h[n]} & = \mathtt{h[h - 1] + \mu[n] * e[n] * x[n]} ; \end{aligned} \]

where:

  • y is the output vector

  • h is the coefficients vector

  • x is the input vector

  • L is the filter order

  • e is the error vector

  • d is the desired vector

  • \(\mathtt{\mu}\) is the step size, which can adjust coefficients and is related to the normalized input signals

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structure for the following data types: single-precision floating point, Q31, and Q15.

Ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures before using the NLMS filter functions. The functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_nlms_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_nlms_f32 (riscv_dsp_nlms_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * ref, float32_t * dst, float32_t * err, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_nlms_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point NLMS filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * coeff;
    float32_t mu;
    float32_t energy
} riscv_dsp_nlms_f32_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

mu

Step size that can adjust coefficients

energy

Energy of the previous frame

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] ref

Pointer to the desired vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[out] err

Pointer to the error vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define coeff_size    5
#define size          6
#define mu            0.05
#define energy        0.1
float32_t state[coeff_size + size - 1] = {0.0};
float32_t coeff[coeff_size] = {0.40, 0.10, 0.24, -0.40, -0.34};
float32_t src[size] = {1.0, 0.5, 0.4, -0.1, -0.1, 0.3};
float32_t ref[size] = {0.1, 0.2, -0.1, -0.02, -0.1, 0.2};
float32_t err[size];
float32_t dst[size];

riscv_dsp_nlms_f32_t instance = {coeff_size, state, coeff, mu, energy};
riscv_dsp_nlms_f32 (&instance, src, ref, dst, err, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 NLMS filter functions.

riscv_dsp_nlms_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_nlms_q31 (riscv_dsp_nlms_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * ref, q31_t * dst, q31_t * err, uint32_t size);
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_nlms_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 NLMS filter, defined as follows: typedef struct { uint32_t coeff_size; q31_t * state; q31_t * coeff; q31_t mu; uint8_t postshift; q31_t energy q31_t x0; } riscv_dsp_nlms_q31_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

mu

Step size that can adjust coefficients

postshift

Shift bits

energy

Energy of the previous frame

x0

Previous input sample

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] ref

Pointer to the desired vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[out] err

Pointer to the error vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_nlms_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_nlms_q15 (riscv_dsp_nlms_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * ref, q15_t * dst, q15_t * err, uint32_t size);
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_nlms_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 NLMS filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t coeff_size;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * coeff;
    q15_t mu;
    uint8_t postshift;
    q15_t energy
    q15_t x0;
} riscv_dsp_nlms_q15_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is coeff_size + size - 1

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

mu

Step size that can adjust coefficients

postshift

Shift bits

energy

Energy of the previous frame

x0

Previous input sample

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] ref

Pointer to the desired vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[out] err

Pointer to the error vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Sparse FIR Filter Functions

These functions are FIR filters in which most coefficients are zero. Because of this, sparse FIR filters retain only the non-zero coefficients and skip the multiplication operations involving signal and zero coefficients.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7.

Ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures before using the sparse FIR filter functions. The functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_spafir_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_spafir_f32 (riscv_dsp_spafir_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, float32_t * buf, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_spafir_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point sparse FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint16_t coeff_size;
    uint16_t index;
    float32_t * state;
    float32_t * coeff;
    uint16_t delay;
    int32_t * nezdelay;
} riscv_dsp_spafir_f32_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

index

Index of the state buffer

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is delay + size

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

delay

Maximum value in the nezdelay vector

nezdelay

Vector that stores non-zero coefficients and the size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] buf

Pointer to the temporary vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

The size of the temporary buffer should be equal to size, which represents the size of the input vector.

Example

The following formula represents the example:

\[ \begin{aligned} \mathtt{y(n)} & = \mathtt{coeff(0) * x(n - nezdelay(0))} + \mathtt{coeff(1) * x(n - ne2delay(1))} \, + \\ & \quad \, \, \mathtt{coeff(2) * x(n - nezdelay(2))} + \mathtt{coeff(3) * x(n - nezdelay(3))} \end{aligned} \]

 

#define coeff_size    4
#define index         1
#define size          6
int32_t nezdelay[coeff_size] = {3, 0, 2, 1};
#define delay         3

float32_t state[delay + size] = {0.0};
float32_t coeff[coeff_size] = {0.40, 0.10, 0.24, -0.40};
float32_t src[size] = {1.0, 0.5, 0.4, -0.1, -0.1, 0.3};
float32_t buf[size];
float32_t dst[size];

riscv_dsp_spafir_f32_t instance = {coeff_size, index, state, coeff, delay, nezdelay};
riscv_dsp_spafir_f32 (&instance, src, dst, buf, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31, Q15, and Q7 sparse FIR filter functions.

riscv_dsp_spafir_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_spafir_q31 (riscv_dsp_spafir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, q31_t * buf, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_spafir_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 sparse FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint16_t coeff_size;
    uint16_t index;
    q31_t * state;
    q31_t * coeff;
    uint16_t delay;
    int32_t * nezdelay;
} riscv_dsp_spafir_q31_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

index

Index of the state buffer

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is delay + size

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

delay

Maximum value in the nezdelay vector

nezdelay

Vector that stores non-zero coefficients and the size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] buf

Pointer to the temporary vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

The size of the temporary buffer should be equal to size, which represents the size of the input vector.

riscv_dsp_spafir_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_spafir_q15 (riscv_dsp_spafir_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, q15_t * buf1, q31_t * buf2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_spafir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 sparse FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint16_t coeff_size;
    uint16_t index;
    q15_t * state;
    q15_t * coeff;
    uint16_t delay;
    int32_t * nezdelay;
} riscv_dsp_spafir_q15_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

index

Index of the state buffer

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is delay + size

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

delay

Maximum value in the nezdelay vector

nezdelay

Vector that stores non-zero coefficients and the size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] buf1

Pointer to the temporary buffer 1

[in] buf2

Pointer to the temporary buffer 2

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

Both temporary buffers 1 and 2 should have a size equal to size, which represents the size of the input vector.

riscv_dsp_spafir_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_spafir_q7 (riscv_dsp_spafir_q7_t * instance, q7_t * src, q7_t * dst, q7_t * buf1, q31_t * buf2, uint32_t size)

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_spafir_q7_t

Instance structure of the Q7 sparse FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint16_t coeff_size;
    uint16_t index;
    q7_t * state;
    q7_t * coeff;
    uint16_t delay;
    int32_t * nezdelay;
} riscv_dsp_spafir_q7_t;

where:

coeff_size

Number of filter coefficients

index

Index of the state buffer

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is delay + size

coeff

Pointer to the coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

delay

Maximum value in the nezdelay vector

nezdelay

Vector that stores non-zero coefficients and the size is coeff_size

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] buf1

Pointer to the temporary buffer 1

[in] buf2

Pointer to the temporary buffer 2

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

Both temporary buffers 1 and 2 should have a size equal to size, which represents the size of the input vector.

Upsampling FIR Filter Functions

These functions upsample incoming signals to generate multirate outputs. They are usually used in audio/sound or images processing, such as increasing the resolution of images or adjusting the audio output sample rate from 16kbps to 32kbps.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions and instance structures for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15.

Ensure that you initialize the corresponding instance structures before using the upsampling filter functions. The functions and their instance structures are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_upsplfir_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_upsplfir_f32 (const riscv_dsp_upsplfir_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_upsplfir_f32_t

Instance structure of the floating-point upsampling FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t L;
    uint32_t plen;
    float32_t * coeff;
    float32_t * state;
} riscv_dsp_upsplfir_f32_t;

where:

L

Upsampling factor

plen

Number of coefficients

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is L * plen

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is plen + size - 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Example
#define L       2
#define plen    4
#define size    6
float32_t state[plen + size - 1] = {0.0};
float32_t coeff[L * plen] = {0.40, 0.10, 0.24, -0.40, 1.0, 0.5, 0.4, -0.1};
float32_t src[size] = {1.0, 0.5, 0.4, -0.1, -0.1, 0.3};
float32_t dst[size * L];
riscv_dsp_upsplfir_f32_t instance = {L, plen, state, coeff};
riscv_dsp_upsplfir_f32 (&instance, src, dst, size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 upsampling FIR filter functions.

riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q31 (const riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q31_t * instance, q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 upsampling FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t L;
    uint32_t plen;
    q31_t * coeff;
    q31_t * state;
} riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q31_t;

L

Upsampling factor

plen

Number of coefficients

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is L * plen

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is plen + size - 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function represents both coefficients and state variables in 1.31 format, yields the multiplication results in 2.62 format, and accumulates the results using a 64-bit accumulator. After completing all operations, it truncates the results to 1.32 format and then saturates them to 1.31 format.

riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q15 (const riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q15_t * instance, q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 upsampling FIR filter, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t L;
    uint32_t plen;
    q15_t * coeff;
    q15_t * state;
} riscv_dsp_upsplfir_q15_t;

where:

L

Upsampling factor

plen

Number of coefficients

coeff

Pointer to the time reversed coefficient vector whose size is L * plen

state

Pointer to the state vector whose size is plen + size - 1

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of samples
Returns

None

Note

This function represents both coefficients and state variables in 1.15 format and yields the multiplication results in 2.30 format. It uses a 64-bit accumulator to accumulate the results in 34.30 format, and then truncates them to 34.15 format by discarding the lower 15 bits. Finally, it saturates the outputs to produce a result in 1.15 format.

Levinson Durbin Functions

These functions calculate the coefficients of an autoregressive linear process.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point and Q31. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_levinson_durbin_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_levinson_durbin_f32 (const float32_t * src, float32_t * coeff, float32_t * err, uint32_t coeff_size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input autocovariance vector starting with lag 0 and having a size of coeff_size + 1

[out] coeff

Pointer to the output autoregressive coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[out] err

Pointer to the output prediction error

[in] coeff_size

Number of autoregressive coefficients
Returns

None

Example
#define coeff_dize    4
float32_t src[coeff_dize + 1] = {0.3, 0.2, -0.1, 0.2, 0.4};
float32_t coeff[coeff_dize] = {-0.1, 0.3, 0.2, -0.2};
float32_t err;
riscv_dsp_levinson_durbin_f32 (src, coeff, &err, coeff_size);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16 and Q31 Levinson-Durbin functions.

riscv_dsp_levinson_durbin_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_levinson_durbin_f16 (const float16_t * src, float16_t * coeff, float16_t * err, uint32_t coeff_size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input autocovariance vector starting with lag 0 and having a size of coeff_size + 1

[out] coeff

Pointer to the output autoregressive coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[out] err

Pointer to the output prediction error

[in] coeff_size

Number of autoregressive coefficients
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_levinson_durbin_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_levinson_durbin_q31 (const q31_t * src, q31_t * coeff, q31_t * err, uint32_t coeff_size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input autocovariance vector starting with lag 0 and having a size of coeff_size + 1

[out] coeff

Pointer to the output autoregressive coefficient vector whose size is coeff_size

[out] err

Pointer to the output prediction error

[in] coeff_size

Number of autoregressive coefficients
Returns

None

Matrix Functions

A matrix can be viewed as a rectangular array with m rows, n columns, and a total of m * n elements. For programming convenience, matrices in Andes DSP library are stored as vectors in row-major order. The size of a vector equals to the total number of elements in the matrix (i.e., size = m * n).

Matrix Addition Functions

These functions add two elements from two source vectors and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ size = row * col; \\ for (i = 0; \, \, i < size; \, \, i++) \\ \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[i] = src1[i] + src2[i];} } \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_add_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_add_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Example

The following equation shows the addition of two matrices and the results.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{0.4} \\ \mathtt{-0.2} & \mathtt{0.1} \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{-0.2} & \mathtt{-0.1} \\ \mathtt{0.3} & \mathtt{0.5} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{-0.1} & \mathtt{0.3} \\ \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{0.6} \end{bmatrix} \]

 

The code example with this function is as follows:

#define row    2
#define col    2
float32_t src1[row * col] = {0.1, 0.4, -0.2, 0.1};
float32_t src2[row * col] = {-0.2, -0.1, 0.3, 0.5};
float32_t dst[row * col];
riscv_dsp_mat_add_f32 (src1, src2, dst, row, col);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, and Q15 matrix addition functions.

riscv_dsp_mat_add_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_add_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_add_f64

void riscv_dsp_mat_add_f64 (const float64_t * src1, const float64_t * src2, float64_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)

Parameter Description

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_mat_add_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_add_q31 (const q31_t * src1, const q31_t * src2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q31 range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF].

riscv_dsp_mat_add_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_add_q15 (const q15_t * src1, const q15_t * src2, q15_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q15 range [0x8000, 0x7FFF].

Matrix Inverse Functions

Matrix inverse functions return the inverse of a square matrix. Since a square matrix has equal dimensions in both horizontal and vertical directions, the function accepts a single parameter (e.g., size) to specify the number of rows and columns. This not only prevents receiving different values for rows and columns but also slightly improves performance.

Matrix inverse functions use Gauss-Jordan elimination to find the inverse of a matrix. First, the output matrix is initialized with 0s and 1s to form an identity matrix. Then, elementary row operations are applied simultaneously to both input and output matrices, transforming the input matrix into an identity matrix.

If the original input matrix is invertible, the function transforms the output matrix into its inverse and returns 0. The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ \left[ A \mid I \right] \xrightarrow{} \text{elementary row operations} \xrightarrow{} \left[ I \mid A^{\scriptstyle -1} \right] } \]

where \(\mathtt{A}\) is the input matrix and \(\mathtt{A^{\scriptstyle -1}}\) is its inverse matrix. Additionally, \(\mathtt{I}\) is an identity matrix generated in the output matrix before elementary row operations and found in the input matrix after the operations.

If the pivot value is zero during elementary row operations, the function searches for a non-zero pivot in the subsequent rows. Once it is found, it swaps the two rows and continues with the elementary row operations until the input matrix is transformed into an identity matrix. If no non-zero pivot is available, the function returns -1, indicating the input matrix is singular.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_inv_f32

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_mat_inv_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] size

Number of rows/columns in a matrix (i.e., size = rows = columns)
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if a non-zero pivot is unavailable

Note

  • If the returned value is 0, the input matrix is invertible and has been transformed into an identity matrix. If the returned value is -1, the input matrix is singular.

  • Regardless of the returned value, the contents of both the input and output matrices will be modified after executing the matrix inverse function.

Example

A square matrix (\(\mathtt{A}\)) and its inverse are listed below:

\[ \mathtt{A} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{0.4} \\ \mathtt{-0.2} & \mathtt{-0.3} \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathtt{inv}(A) = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{-6} & \mathtt{-8} \\ \mathtt{4} & \mathtt{2} \end{bmatrix} \]

The code example for getting the inverse of matrix \(\mathtt{A}\) is as follows:

#define size    2
float32_t src[size * size] = {0.1, 0.4, -0.2, -0.3};
float32_t dst[size * size];
if (riscv_dsp_mat_inv_f32 (src, dst, size) == 0)
    Success...
else
    Fail...

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16 and F64 matrix inverse functions.

riscv_dsp_mat_inv_f16

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_mat_inv_f16 (float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] size

Number of rows/columns in a matrix (i.e, size = rows = columns)
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if a non-zero pivot is unavailable

Note

  • If the returned value is 0, the input matrix is invertible and has been transformed into an identity matrix. If the returned value is -1, the input matrix is singular.

  • Regardless of the returned value, the contents of both the input and output matrices will be modified after executing the matrix inverse function.

  • This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_inv_f64

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_mat_inv_f64 (float64_t * src, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] size

Number of rows/columns in a matrix (i.e., size = rows = columns)
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if a non-zero pivot is unavailable

Note

  • If the returned value is 0, the input matrix is invertible and has been transformed into an identity matrix. If the returned value is -1, the input matrix is singular.

  • Regardless of the returned value, the contents of both the input and output matrices will be modified after executing the matrix inverse function.

Matrix Multiplication Functions

These functions compute the multiplication of two source matrices and store the results in a destination matrix.

The following matrix shows the multiplication of matrix \(\mathtt{A}\) by matrix \(\mathtt{B}\), in which both matrices have two rows and two columns.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 12}} \\ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 22}} \end{bmatrix} * \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} & \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12}} \\ \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} & \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 22}} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} + A_{\scriptscriptstyle 12} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12} + A_{\scriptscriptstyle 12} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 22}} \\ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} + A_{\scriptscriptstyle 22} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12} + A_{\scriptscriptstyle 22} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 22}} \end{bmatrix} \]

According to the definition of matrix multiplication, the number of rows in matrix \(\mathtt{B}\) must be identical to the number of columns in matrix \(\mathtt{A}\). That is,

\[ \mathtt{ C_{\scriptscriptstyle ik} = A_{\scriptscriptstyle ij} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle jk} } \]

where \(\mathtt{A}\) is a matrix with \(\mathtt{i}\) rows and \(\mathtt{j}\) columns, \(\mathtt{B}\) is a matrix with \(\mathtt{j}\) rows and \(\mathtt{k}\) columns, and \(\mathtt{C}\) is the destination matrix with \(\mathtt{i}\) rows and \(\mathtt{k}\) columns.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_mul_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col, uint32_t col2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in the first matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in the first matrix

[in] col2

Number of columns in the second matrix
Returns

None

Example

The following equation shows the multiplication of two matrices and the results.

\[\mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 2,3} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 3,2}} = C_{\scriptscriptstyle 2,2}\]

 

The code example with this function is as follows:

#define Arow    2
#define Acol    3
#define Bcol    2
float32_t src1[Arow * Acol] = {0.1, -0.1, 0.1, 0.2, -0.2, 0.3};
float32_t src2[Acol * Bcol] = {0.2, 0.2, -0.1, 0.3, -0.7, -0.2};
float32_t dst[Arow * Bcol];
riscv_dsp_mat_mul_f32 (src1, src2, dst, Arow, Acol, Bcol);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, Q15, and Q7 matrix multiplication functions.

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_f16

For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_fast_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_mul_fast_q31 (const q31_t * src1, const q31_t * src2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col, uint32_t col2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in the first matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in the first matrix

[in] col2

Number of columns in the second matrix
Returns

None

Note

  • This function uses a 32-bit accumulator to perform multiply-accumulate operations and truncates the results to Q2.30 format.

    To avoid overflow, scale down the input matrix by log2(row) bits before calling this function.

    After completing all operations, it saturates the results and converts them to Q1.31 format.

  • When compared with riscv_dsp_mat_mul_q31, this function delivers higher performance with lower precision.

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_mul_q15 (const q15_t * src1, const q15_t * src2, q15_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col, uint32_t col2)

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in the first matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in the first matrix

[in] col2

Number of columns in the second matrix
Returns

None

Note

For RV64, this function allocates a temporary buffer of 256 bytes to ensure efficient calculation.

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_fast_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_mul_fast_q15 (const q15_t * src1, const q15_t * src2, q15_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col, uint32_t col2)

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_vxm_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_mul_vxm_q7 (const q7_t * src1, const q7_t * src2, q7_t * dst, uint32_t col, uint32_t col2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to an input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to an input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] col

Number of columns in the input vector

[in] col2

Number of columns in the input matrix
Returns

None

Note

This function multiplies a vector of col columns, src1[1, col], by a matrix with col rows and col2 columns, src2[col, col2], and stores the result in a vector with col2 columns, dst[1, col2].

Matrix Scale Functions

These functions multiply a matrix by a constant scaling value and store the results in a destination matrix.

Since vectors serve as containers of matrices in Andes DSP library, the behavior of matrix scale functions can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{size = m * n;} \\ & \mathtt{for \, \, (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[i] = src[i] * scale;} \end{aligned} \]

Due to fractional representation, you can use the input parameter shift to adjust the range of result values. For more details about the parameter, see the functions with fractional data types in riscv_dsp_mat_scale_q31 and riscv_dsp_mat_scale_q15.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_scale_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_scale_f32 (const float32_t * src, float32_t scale, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[in] scale

Constant scaling value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Example

Given a matrix and a scale value 0.2, the matrix scale equation is as follows:

\[ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{0.4} \\ \mathtt{-0.2} & \mathtt{0.1} \end{bmatrix} * \mathtt{scale} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.02} & \mathtt{0.08} \\ \mathtt{-0.04} & \mathtt{0.02} \end{bmatrix} \]

and its code example is like:

#define row    2
#define col    2
float32_t src[row * col] = {0.1, 0.4, -0.2, 0.1};
flaot32_t scale = 0.2;
float32_t dst[row * col];
riscv_dsp_mat_scale_f32 (src, scale, dst, row, col);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, and Q15 matrix scale functions.

riscv_dsp_mat_scale_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_scale_f16 (const float16_t * src, float16_t scale, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[in] scale

Constant scaling value

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_scale_f64

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Matrix Subtraction Functions

These functions subtract two matrices of the same dimensions and store the results in a destination matrix.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{size = m * n;} \\ & \mathtt{for \, \, (i = 0; \, \, i < size; \, \, i++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[i] = src1[i] - src2[i];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_sub_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_sub_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Example

The following equation shows the subtraction of two matrices and the results.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{0.4} \\ \mathtt{-0.2} & \mathtt{0.1} \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{-0.2} & \mathtt{-0.1} \\ \mathtt{0.3} & \mathtt{0.5} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.3} & \mathtt{0.5} \\ \mathtt{-0.5} & \mathtt{-0.4} \end{bmatrix} \]

 

The code example with this function is as follows:

#define row    2
#define col    2
float32_t src1[row * col] = {0.1, 0.4, -0.2, 0.1};
float32_t src2[row * col] = {-0.2, -0.1, 0.3, 0.5};
float32_t dst[row * col];
riscv_dsp_mat_sub_f32 (src1, src2, dst, row, col);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, and Q15 matrix subtraction functions.

riscv_dsp_mat_sub_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_sub_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_sub_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_sub_f64 (const float64_t * src1, const float64_t * src2, float64_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_mat_sub_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_sub_q31 (const q31_t * src1, const q31_t * src2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q31 range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF].

riscv_dsp_mat_sub_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_sub_q15 (const q15_t * src1, const q15_t * src2, q15_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Note

The results are saturated to the Q15 range [0x8000, 0x7FFF].

Matrix Transpose Functions

These functions transpose a matrix and store the results in a destination matrix. The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ dst[n, m] = src[m, n] } \]

where \(\mathtt{0 \leq m < row}\) and \(\mathtt{0 \leq n < col}\).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_trans_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_trans_f32 (const float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Example

Given an equation of matrix transposing like below:

\[ \mathtt{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{-0.1} & \mathtt{0.1} \\ \mathtt{0.2} & \mathtt{-0.2} & \mathtt{0.3} \end{bmatrix} }^{\scriptscriptstyle{T}} = \mathtt{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{0.2} \\ \mathtt{-0.1} & \mathtt{-0.2} \\ \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{0.3} \end{bmatrix} } \]

and its code example is as follows:

#define row    2
#define col    3
float32_t src[row * col] = {0.1, -0.1, 0.1, 0.2, -0.2, 0.3};
float32_t dst[col * row];
riscv_dsp_mat_trans_f32 (src, dst, row, col);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8 matrix transpose functions.

riscv_dsp_mat_trans_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_trans_f16 (const float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)

[out] dst

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

None

Matrix Power 2 Function

This function squares a matrix and stores the results in a destination matrix. The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ dst = src^{\scriptscriptstyle 2} } \]

where \(\mathtt{src}\) represents a square matrix.

Andes DSP library only supports functions for the double-precision floating-point data type.

riscv_dsp_mat_pwr2_cache_f64

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_mat_pwr2_cache_f64 (const float64_t * src, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] size

Number of rows or columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if the operation fails

Note

The input matrix must be square, with the number of rows or columns equal to size. Additionally, size must be a multiple of four (e.g., 28, 32, 64, and 1024). If these conditions are not met, the function returns -1 to indicate an error.

This function performs block matrix multiplication. The block size corresponds to the size of one cache line, optimizing memory access and reducing cache misses.

For size values smaller than 40, it is recommended to use riscv_dsp_mat_mul_f64 for better performance.

Matrix Outer Product Function

This function computes the multiplication of two source vectors and stores the results in a destination matrix.

The following matrix shows the multiplication of vector \(\mathtt{A}\) by vector \(\mathtt{B}\), in which vector \(\mathtt{A}\) has three rows and vector \(\mathtt{B}\) has four columns.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} \\ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} \\ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 31}} \end{bmatrix} * \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} & \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12}} & \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 13}} & \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 14}} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 13}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 14}} \\ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 13}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 14}} \\ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 31} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 31} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 31} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 13}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 31} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 14}} \end{bmatrix} \]

The outer product can be treated as a matrix multiplication where the source matrices \(\mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle ij}}\) and \(\mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle jk}}\) have the constraint that \(\mathtt{j}\) must be 1, as shown below.

\[ \mathtt{ C_{\scriptscriptstyle ik} = A_{\scriptscriptstyle ij} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle jk} } \]

where \(\mathtt{j = 1}\).

Andes DSP library only supports functions for the Q31 data type.

riscv_dsp_mat_oprod_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_oprod_q31 (const q31_t * src1, const q31_t * src2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size1, uint32_t size2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input matrix with a size of size1 * 1

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input matrix with a size of 1 * size2

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix with a size of size1 * size2

[in] size1

Number of rows in the first input matrix

[in] size2

Number of columns in the second input matrix
Returns

None

Note

This function multiplies a one-column matrix with size1 rows, src1[size1, 1], with a one-row matrix with size2 columns, src2[1, size2], and stores the results in a matrix with size1 rows and size2 columns, dst[size1, size2]. It achieves better efficiency for vector-wise matrix multiplication compared to regular matrix multiplication.

Example

The following equation shows the outer product of two matrices and the results.

\[ \mathtt{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0x200000} \\ \mathtt{0x100000} \\ \mathtt{0x50000} \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0x10000} & \mathtt{0x30000} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0x40} & \, \mathtt{0xc0} \\ \mathtt{0x20} & \, \mathtt{0x60} \\ \mathtt{0xa} & \, \mathtt{0x1e} \end{bmatrix} } \]

and its code example is like:

#define Arow    3
#define Bcol    2
q31_t src1[Arow] = {0x200000, 0x100000, 0x50000};
q31_t src2[Bcol] = {0x10000, 0x30000};
q31_t dst[Arow * Bcol];
riscv_dsp_mat_oprod_q31 (src1, src2, dst, Arow, Bcol);

Complex Matrix Multiplication Functions

These functions compute the multiplication of two source complex matrices and store the results in a destination complex matrix.

The following matrix shows the multiplication of matrix \(\mathtt{A}\) by matrix \(\mathtt{B}\), in which both matrices have two rows and two columns.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 12}} \\ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 22}} \end{bmatrix} * \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11}} & \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12}} \\ \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} & \mathtt{B_{\scriptscriptstyle 22}} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} + A_{\scriptscriptstyle 12} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12} + A_{\scriptscriptstyle 12} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 22}} \\ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 11} + A_{\scriptscriptstyle 22} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 21}} & \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle 21} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 12} + A_{\scriptscriptstyle 22} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 22}} \end{bmatrix} \]

and each multiplication is treated as a complex multiplication.

\[ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle n} = a_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (re) + a_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (im) \, i, \, \, B_{\scriptscriptstyle n} = b_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (re) + b_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (im) \, i;} \] \[ \mathtt{A_{\scriptscriptstyle n} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle n} = (a_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (re) * b_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (re) - a_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (im) * b_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (im)) \, \, +} \] \[ \quad \quad \mathtt{(a_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (re) * b_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (im) + a_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (im) * b_{\scriptscriptstyle n} \, (re)) \, i} \]

According to the definition of matrix multiplication, the number of rows in complex matrix \(\mathtt{B}\) must be identical to the number of columns in matrix \(\mathtt{A}\). That is,

\[ \mathtt{ C_{\scriptscriptstyle ik} = A_{\scriptscriptstyle ij} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle jk} } \]

where \(\mathtt{A}\) is a matrix with \(\mathtt{i}\) rows and \(\mathtt{j}\) columns, \(\mathtt{B}\) is a matrix with \(\mathtt{j}\) rows and \(\mathtt{k}\) columns, and \(\mathtt{C}\) is the destination matrix with \(\mathtt{i}\) rows and \(\mathtt{k}\) columns.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cmat_mul_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmat_mul_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col, uint32_t col2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in the first complex matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in the first complex matrix

[in] col2

Number of columns in the second complex matrix
Returns

None

Example

The following equation shows the multiplication of two complex matrices and the results.

\[ \mathtt{ A_{\scriptscriptstyle 2,3} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 3,2} = C_{\scriptscriptstyle 2,2} } \]
 

Given each element with a value, the result is like:

\[ \mathtt{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1 + 0.2i} & \mathtt{-0.1 - 0.3i} & \mathtt{0.1 + 0.4i} \\ \mathtt{0.2 - 0.1i} & \mathtt{-0.2 + 0.5i} & \mathtt{0.3 - 0.4i} \end{bmatrix} } * \mathtt{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.2 + 0.5i} & \mathtt{0.2 - 0.4i} \\ \mathtt{-0.1 + 0.2i} & \mathtt{0.3 + 0.2i} \\ \mathtt{-0.7 - 0.4i} & \mathtt{-0.2 - 0.1i} \end{bmatrix} } = \mathtt{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.08 - 0.22i} & \mathtt{0.15 - 0.2i} \\ \mathtt{-0.36 + 0.15i} & \mathtt{-0.26 + 0.6i} \end{bmatrix} } \]

 

and can be presented in code with this function as follows:

#define Arow    2
#define Acol    3
#define Bcol    2
float32_t src1[2 * Arow * Acol] = {0.1, 0.2, -0.1, -0.3, 0.1, 0.4, 0.2, -0.1, -0.2, 0.5, 0.3, -0.4};
float32_t src2[2 * Acol * Bcol] = {0.2, 0.5, 0.2, -0.4, -0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.2, -0.7, -0.4, -0.2, -0.1};
float32_t dst[2 * Arow * Bcol];
riscv_dsp_cmat_mul_f32 (src1, src2, dst, Arow, Acol, Bcol);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, Q31, and Q15 complex matrix multiplication functions.

riscv_dsp_cmat_mul_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmat_mul_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col, uint32_t col2)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input complex matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input complex matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in the first complex matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in the first complex matrix

[in] col2

Number of columns in the second complex matrix
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_cmat_mul_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmat_mul_q31 (const q31_t * src1, const q31_t * src2, q31_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col, uint32_t col2)

riscv_dsp_cmat_mul_q15

Returns

None

Matrix Multiplies Vector Functions

These functions compute the multiplication of a matrix and a vector and store the results in a destination vector.

According to the definition of matrix multiplication, the number of elements in the multiplier vector must be identical to the number of columns in the multiplicand matrix.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_mxv_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_mul_mxv_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] row

Number of rows in the matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in the input matrix and the input vector size
Returns

None

Example

The following equation shows the matrix \(\mathtt{A}\) being multiplied with a vector \(\mathtt{B}\).

\[ \mathtt{ A_{\scriptscriptstyle 2,3} * B_{\scriptscriptstyle 3,1} = C_{\scriptscriptstyle 2,1} } \]
 

Given each element with a value, the result is like:

\[ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1} & \mathtt{-0.1} & \mathtt{0.1} \\ \mathtt{0.2} & \mathtt{-0.2} & \mathtt{0.3} \end{bmatrix} * \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.2} \\ \mathtt{-0.1} \\ \mathtt{-0.7} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{-0.04} \\ \mathtt{-0.15} \end{bmatrix} \]

The code example with this function is as follows:

#define Arow    2
#define Acol    3
float32_t src1[Arow * Acol] = {0.1, -0.1, 0.1, 0.2, -0.2, 0.3};
float32_t src2[Acol] = {0.2, -0.1, -0.7};
float32_t dst[Arow];
riscv_dsp_mat_mul_mxv_f32 (src1, src2, dst, Arow, Acol);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, Q31, Q15, and Q7 matrix multiplies vector functions.

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_mxv_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mat_mul_mxv_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the input matrix

[in] src2

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] row

Number of rows in the matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in the input matrix and the input vector size
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_mul_mxv_q31

[out] dst

[out] dst

[in] row

Number of rows in the matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in the input matrix and the input vector size
Returns

None

Complex Matrix Transpose Functions

These functions transpose a complex matrix and store the results in a destination complex matrix.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_f32 (const float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a complex matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a complex matrix
Returns

None

Example

Given an equation of complex matrix transposing like below:

\[ \mathtt{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1 + 0.2i} & \mathtt{-0.1 + 0.3i} & \mathtt{0.1 - 0.2i} \\ \mathtt{0.2 + 0.0i} & \mathtt{-0.2 - 0.1i} & \mathtt{0.3 - 0.3i} \end{bmatrix} }^{\scriptscriptstyle{T}} = \mathtt{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathtt{0.1 + 0.2i} & \mathtt{0.2 + 0.0i} \\ \mathtt{-0.1 + 0.3i} & \mathtt{-0.2 - 0.1i} \\ \mathtt{0.1 - 0.2i} & \mathtt{0.3 - 0.3i} \end{bmatrix} } \]

and its code example is as follows:

#define row    2
#define col    3
float32_t src[row * col * 2] = {0.1, 0.2, -0.1, 0.3, 0.1, -0.2, 0.2, 0.0, -0.2, -0.1, 0.3. -0.3};
float32_t dst[col * row * 2];
riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_f32 (src, dst, row, col);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, Q31, and Q15 complex matrix transpose functions.

riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_f16 (const float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a complex matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a complex matrix
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_q31 (const q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a complex matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a complex matrix
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cmat_trans_q15 (const q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input complex matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output complex matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a complex matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a complex matrix
Returns

None

Matrix Cholesky Decomposition Functions

These functions perform the Cholesky decomposition of an input matrix and store the results in a destination matrix. They return -1 if the decomposition fails.

The Cholesky decomposition of a matrix \(\mathtt{A}\) is a factorization in the following form:

\[ \mathtt{A = LL^{\scriptscriptstyle T}} \]

where \(\mathtt{L}\) is the destination matrix and is a real lower triangular matrix with positive diagonal entries.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_cholesky_f32

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_cholesky_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

riscv_dsp_mat_cholesky_f16

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_cholesky_f16 (float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_cholesky_f64

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_cholesky_f64 (float64_t * src, float64_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Matrix LDLT Decomposition Functions

These functions perform the LDLT decomposition of an input matrix and store the results in the destination matrices. They return -1 if the decomposition fails.

The LDLT decomposition of a matrix A is a factorization in the following form:

\[ \mathtt{PAP^{\scriptscriptstyle T}} = \mathtt{LDL^{\scriptscriptstyle T}} \]

where \(\mathtt{P}\) is the destination permutation vector, \(\mathtt{L}\) is the destination matrix and is a real lower unit triangular matrix, and \(\mathtt{D}\) is the destination diagonal matrix.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_ldlt_f32

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_ldlt_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t * dstl, float32_t * dstd, uint16_t * pp, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dstl

Pointer to the output lower triangular matrix

[out] dstd

Pointer to the output diagonal matrix

[out] pp

Pointer to the output permutation vector

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

riscv_dsp_mat_ldlt_f64

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_ldlt_f64 (float64_t * src, float64_t * dstl, float64_t * dstd, uint16_t * pp, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dstl

Pointer to the output lower triangular matrix

[out] dstd

Pointer to the output diagonal matrix

[out] pp

Pointer to the output permutation vector

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Matrix Solve Lower Triangular Functions

These functions perform a lower triangular decomposition on the input matrix and store the results in a destination matrix.

The lower triangular decomposition is solved in the following form:

\[ \mathtt{Lx = A} \]

That is, the destination matrix \(\mathtt{x}\) can be obtained if given the input matrix \(\mathtt{A}\) and the lower triangular matrix \(\mathtt{L}\).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_solve_lt_f32

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_solve_lt_f32 (float32_t * lt, float32_t * A, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] lt

Pointer to the input lower triangular matrix

[in] A

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

riscv_dsp_mat_solve_lt_f16

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_solve_lt_f16 (float16_t * lt, float16_t * A, float16_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] lt

Pointer to the input lower triangular matrix

[in] A

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

[out] dst

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Matrix Solve Upper Triangular Functions

These functions perform an upper triangular decomposition on the input matrix and store the results in a destination matrix.

The upper triangular decomposition is solved in the following form:

\[ \mathtt{Ux = A} \]

That is, the destination matrix \(\mathtt{x}\) can be obtained if given the input matrix \(\mathtt{A}\) and upper triangular matrix \(\mathtt{U}\).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_solve_ut_f32

int riscv_dsp_mat_solve_ut_f32 (float32_t * ut, float32_t * A, float32_t * dst, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)

Pointer to the input upper triangular matrix

[in] A

Pointer to the input matrix

[out] dst

Pointer to the output matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

[in] col
