Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Matrix Householder Transform Functions

These functions perform the Householder transform of a vector \(\mathtt{x}\), producing a vector \(\mathtt{v}\) with \(\mathtt{\|v\| = 1}\) and a scalar \(\mathtt{\beta}\), such that \(\mathtt{H = I - \beta vv^{\scriptstyle T}}\) and \(\mathtt{Hx = \|x\|_{2}e_{1}}\).

In this case, \(\mathtt{H}\) is an orthogonal matrix and a hyperplane reflection, transforming \(\mathtt{x}\) into a vector proportional to \(\mathtt{e_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}\), which has the following coordinates:

\[ \begin{pmatrix} \mathtt{1} \\ \mathtt{0} \\ \mathtt{\vdots} \end{pmatrix} \]

If \(\mathtt{x}\) is already proportional to \(\mathtt{e_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}\), the matrix \(\mathtt{H}\) will be the identity matrix.

The Householder transform functions also help detect whether \(\mathtt{x}\) is already proportional to \(\mathtt{e_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}\).

Give \(\mathtt{x}\) in the form:

\[ \mathtt{x = \begin{pmatrix} \mathtt{x_{0}} \\ \mathtt{xr} \end{pmatrix}} \]

where \(\mathtt{xr}\) is a vector, the algorithm computes the norm squared of \(\mathtt{xr}\) using \(\mathtt{\|xr\|^{\scriptstyle 2}}\). This value is compared to a threshold, which is provided as an argument to the function. If the value is less than the threshold, the algorithm returns 0 for \(\mathtt{\beta}\) and the householder vector, indicating that \(\mathtt{x}\) is already proportional to \(\mathtt{e_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}\).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_householder_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_mat_householder_f32 (const float32_t * src, const float32_t threshold, uint32_t size, float32_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] threshold

Norm2 threshold

[in] size

Number of size in a vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

The scaling factor beta

riscv_dsp_mat_householder_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_mat_householder_f16 (const float16_t * src, const float16_t threshold, uint32_t size, float16_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] threshold

Norm2 threshold

[in] size

Number of size in a vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

The scaling factor beta

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_householder_f64

Declaration
float64_t riscv_dsp_mat_householder_f64 (const float64_t * src, const float64_t threshold, uint32_t size, float16_t * dst)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] threshold

Norm2 threshold

[in] size

Number of size in a vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector
Returns

The scaling factor beta

Matrix QR Decomposition Functions

These functions perform the QR decomposition of a matrix \(\mathtt{M}\) using the Householder algorithm, \(\mathtt{M = QR}\), where \(\mathtt{Q}\) is an orthogonal matrix and \(\mathtt{R}\) is an upper triangular matrix.

The returned value for \(\mathtt{R}\) has the structure:

\[ \begin{pmatrix} \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{11}}} & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{12}}} & \dots & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{1n}}} \\ \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{12}}} & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{22}}} & \dots & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{2n}}} \\ \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{13}}} & \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{23}}} & \dots & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{3n}}} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{1m}}} & \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{2(m-1)}}} & \dots & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{mn}}} \end{pmatrix} \]

where the first Householder reflector is as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ v_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}} = \begin{pmatrix} \mathtt{1} \\ \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{12}}} \\ \vdots \\ \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{1m}}} \end{pmatrix} } \]

The function returns a vector \(\mathtt{\tau}\) that contains the scaling factor for reflectors.

The Householder matrix is given by \(\mathtt{H_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}}\), in which:

\[ \mathtt{ H_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}} = I - \mathtt{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}} \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}} \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{T}}} } \]

The computation of the matrix \(\mathtt{Q}\) is optional. That is, the matrix \(\mathtt{Q}\) can be the product of the Householder matrices \(\mathtt{(Q = H_{1} \, \, H_{2} \, \, \dots \, \, H_{n})}\) or not computed.

The matrix \(\mathtt{R}\) is the returned value for \(\mathtt{R}\) without the Householder reflectors:

\[ \begin{pmatrix} \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{11}}} & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{12}}} & \dots & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{1n}}} \\ \mathtt{0} & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{22}}} & \dots & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{2n}}} \\ \mathtt{0} & \mathtt{v_{\scriptscriptstyle{22}}} & \dots & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{3n}}} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \mathtt{0} & \mathtt{0} & \dots & \mathtt{r_{\scriptscriptstyle{mn}}} \end{pmatrix} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mat_qr_f32

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_qr_f32 (const float32_t * src, const float32_t threshold, float32_t * dstR, float32_t * dstQ, float32_t * tau, float32_t * pTmpA, float32_t * pTmpB, const uint32_t row, const uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix whose size is row * col

[in] threshold

Norm2 threshold

[out] dst R

Pointer to the output matrix \(\mathtt{R}\) whose size is row * col

[out] dst Q

Pointer to the output matrix \(\mathtt{Q}\) whose size is row * row
(can be NULL)

[out] tau

Pointer to the Householder scaling factor whose size is col

[in] pTmpA

Pointer to the temporary vector whose size is row

[in] pTmpB

Pointer to the temporary vector whose size is row

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Note

  • The function performs the QR decomposition of a row * col matrix with row ≥ col.

  • The dstQ parameter can be a NULL pointer. If it is NULL, the parameter is ignored, and the output matrix \(\mathtt{Q}\) will not be computed.

riscv_dsp_mat_qr_f16

Declaration
int riscv_dsp_mat_qr_f16 (const float16_t * src, const float16_t threshold, float16_t * dstR, float16_t * dstQ, float16_t * tau, float16_t * pTmpA, float16_t * pTmpB, const uint32_t row, const uint32_t col)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix whose size is row * col

[in] threshold

Norm2 threshold

[out] dstR

Pointer to the output matrix \(\mathtt{R}\) whose size is row * col

[out] dstQ

Pointer to the output matrix \(\mathtt{Q}\) whose size is row * row
(can be NULL)

[out] tau

Pointer to the householder scaling factor whose size is col

[in] pTmpA

Pointer to the temporary vector whose size is row

[in] pTmpB

Pointer to the temporary vector whose size is row

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Note

  • The function performs the QR decomposition of a row * col matrix with row ≥ col.

  • The dstQ parameter can be a NULL pointer. If it is NULL, the parameter is ignored, and the output matrix \(\mathtt{Q}\) will not be computed.

  • This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_mat_qr_f64

Declaration

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input matrix whose size is row * col

[in] threshold

Norm2 threshold

[out] dstR

Pointer to the output matrix R whose size is row * col

[out] dstQ

(can be NULL)

[in] pTmpA

Pointer to the temporary vector whose size is row

[in] pTmpB

Pointer to the temporary vector whose size is row

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if decomposition fails

Note

  • The function performs the QR decomposition of a row * col matrix with row ≥ col.

  • The dstQ parameter can be a NULL pointer. If it is NULL, the parameter is ignored, and the output matrix \(\mathtt{Q}\) will not be computed.

Statistics Functions

This section includes the following statistics functions.

Maximum Functions

These functions compare values in a vector and return the maximum one along with its index, or just the maximum value.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, U64, U32, U16, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_max_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_max_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size, uint32_t * index)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] index

Pointer to the index of the maximum value
Returns

  • The maximum value if successful

  • -1 if size is less than or equal to zero

riscv_dsp_max_val_f32

Declaration

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

  • The maximum value if successful

  • -1 if size is less than or equal to zero

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

  • The maximum value if successful

  • 0x0 if size is less than or equal to zero

Mean Functions

These functions calculate the arithmetic mean of a vector.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mean_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_mean_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The mean value

riscv_dsp_mean_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_mean_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The mean value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Minimum Functions

These functions compare values in a vector and return the minimum one along with its index, or just the minimum value.

Andes DSP library supports distinct minimum functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, U64, U32, U16, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_min_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_min_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size, uint32_t * index)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] index

Pointer to the index of the minimum value
Returns

  • The minimum value if successful

  • -1 if size is less than or equal to zero

[out] index

Pointer to the index of the minimum value
Returns

  • The minimum value if successful

  • -1 if size is less than or equal to zero

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

  • The minimum value if successful

  • 0xff if size is less than or equal to zero

Root Mean Square (RMS) Functions

These functions compute root mean square of a vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{RMS = sqrt\left(\frac{ (\mathtt{src[0]^{\scriptstyle{2}}} + \mathtt{src[1]^{\scriptstyle{2}}} + \dots + \mathtt{src[size-1]^{\scriptstyle{2}}}) }{\mathtt{size}} \right)} \]

See Square Root (SQRT) Functions for more details about square root functions.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_rms_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_rms_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The RMS value

riscv_dsp_rms_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_rms_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The RMS value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_rms_q31

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_rms_q31 (const q31_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The RMS value

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The RMS value

Power Functions

These functions compute the sum of squares of a vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{sos = src[0]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}} + src[1]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}} + \dots + src[size-1]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}}} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_pwr_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_pwr_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The sum of squares

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_pwr_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The sum of squares

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The sum of squares

Note

The returned value is in Q48 format.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The sum of squares

Note

The returned value is in Q30 format.

riscv_dsp_pwr_q7

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_pwr_q7 (const q7_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The sum of squares

Note

The returned value is in Q14 format.

Standard Deviation Functions

These functions compute the The standard deviation value of a vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{sos = src[0]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}} + src[1]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}} + \dots + src[size-1]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}}} \]
\[ \mathtt{sqrsum = (src[0] + src[1] + \dots + src[size-1])^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}}} \]
\[ \mathtt{std = sqrt\left(\frac{sos - {\frac{sqrsum}{size}}}{size - 1}\right)} \]

See Square Root (SQRT) Functions for more details about square root functions.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_std_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_std_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The standard deviation value

riscv_dsp_std_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_std_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The standard deviation value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Returns

The standard deviation value

Parameters

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The standard deviation value

Variance Functions

These functions compute the The variance value of a vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{sos = src[0]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}} + src[1]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}} + \dots + src[size-1]^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}}} \]
\[ \mathtt{sqrsum = (src[0] + src[1] + \dots + src[size-1])^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}}} \]
\[ \mathtt{var = \frac{sos - {\frac{sqrsum}{size}}}{size - 1}} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_var_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_var_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The variance value

riscv_dsp_var_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_var_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The variance value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Pointer to the input vector

Returns

The variance value

Parameter Description

Entropy Functions

These function computes the entropy of a vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ Entropy = - \left(\sum_{i=0}^{\mathtt{size-1}} src[i] * \mathtt{{ln}(src[i])} \right) } \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_entropy_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_entropy_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The entropy value

riscv_dsp_entropy_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_entropy_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The entropy value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_entropy_f64

Declaration
float64_t riscv_dsp_entropy_f64 (const float64_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The entropy value

Relative Entropy Functions

These functions compute the entropy of two vectors, commonly referred to as the Kullback-Leibler divergence (DKL).

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ D_{\scriptscriptstyle{KL}}(src1 \, \| \, src2) = - \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} src1[i] * \mathtt{ln}\left(\frac{src2[i]}{src1[i]}\right) \right) } \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_relative_entropy_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_relative_entropy_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The relative entropy value

[in] size

Returns

The relative entropy value

Log-Sum-Exp (LSE) Functions

These functions compute the logarithm of the sum of the exponentials of a vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[$$ \mathtt{ LSE(src_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}, \, \dots, \, src_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}}) = src^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}} + \mathtt{log\left(\mathtt{exp\left(src_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}} - src^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}}\right)} + \dots + \mathtt{exp\left(src_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}} - src^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}}\right)}\right)} } $$\]

where \(\mathtt{src^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}} = \mathtt{max\{src_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}, \, \dots, \, src_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}}\}}}\).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_lse_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_lse_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The LSE value

riscv_dsp_lse_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_lse_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The LSE value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Log-Sum-Exp (LSE) Dot Product Functions

These functions compute the logarithm of the sum of the exponentials of the dot product of two vectors.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[$$ \mathtt{ LSE(X_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}, \, \dots, \, X_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}}) = X^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}} + \mathtt{log\left(\mathtt{\exp\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}} - X^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}}\right)} + \dots + \mathtt{exp\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}} - X^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}}\right)}\right)} } $$\]

where \(\mathtt{X^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}} = \mathtt{max\{X_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}, \dots, X_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}}\}, \, X_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}} = src1[n] + src2[n]}}\).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_lse_dprod_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_lse_dprod_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size, float32_t * buffer)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[in] buffer

Pointer to the temporary buffer
Returns

The LSE dot product value

riscv_dsp_lse_dprod_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_lse_dprod_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, uint32_t size, float16_t * buffer)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[in] buffer

Pointer to the temporary buffer
Returns

The LSE dot product value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Naive Gaussian Bayesian Estimator Functions

These functions implement the naive Gaussian Bayes estimator.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_gaussian_naive_bayes_est_f32

Declaration
uint32_t riscv_dsp_gaussian_naive_bayes_est_f32 (const riscv_dsp_gaussian_naivebayes_f32_t * instance, const float32_t * src, float32_t * buf)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_gaussian_naivebayes_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 naive Gaussian Bayesian estimation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t dimofvec;
    uint32_t numofclass;
    const float32_t * mean;
    const float32_t * var;
    const float32_t * classprior;
    float32_t additiveofvar;
} riscv_dsp_gaussian_naivebayes_f32_t;

where:

dimofvec

Dimension of vector space

numofclass

Number of classes

mean

Mean value for the Gaussian whose size is dimofvec * numofclass

var

Variance for the Gaussian whose size is dimofvec * numofclass

classprior

Class prior probabilities whose size is numofclass

additiveofvar

Additive value of variance

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] buf

Pointer to the buffer vector
Returns

The estimated class

riscv_dsp_gaussian_naive_bayes_est_f16

Declaration
uint32_t riscv_dsp_gaussian_naive_bayes_est_f16 (const riscv_dsp_gaussian_naivebayes_f16_t * instance, const float16_t * src, float16_t * buf)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_gaussian_naivebayes_f16_t

Instance structure of the F16 naive Gaussian Bayesian estimation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t dimofvec;
    uint32_t numofclass;
    const float16_t * mean;
    const float16_t * var;
    const float16_t * classprior;
    float16_t additiveofvar;
} riscv_dsp_gaussian_naivebayes_f16_t;

where:

dimofvec

Dimension of vector space

numofclass

Number of classes

mean

Mean value for the Gaussian whose size is dimofvec * numofclass

var

Variance for the Gaussian whose size is dimofvec * numofclass

classprior

Class prior probabilities whose size is numofclass

additiveofvar

Additive value of variance

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] buf

Pointer to the buffer vector
Returns

The estimated class

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Absolute Maximum Functions

These functions compare absolute values in a vector and return the maximum one along with its index, or just the maximum value.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_absmax_f32

Declaration

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] index

Pointer to the index of the absolute maximum value
Returns

  • The absolute maximum value if successful

  • -1 if size is equal to zero

Mean Square Error (MSE) Functions

These functions compute the MSE value between two vectors.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ MSE = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=0}^{N} \left(src1[i] - src2[i]\right)^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}} } \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31 , Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mse_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mse_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size, float32_t * result)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] result

Pointer to the MSE value
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_mse_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mse_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, uint32_t size, float16_t * result)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] result

Pointer to the MSE value
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Accumulation Functions

These functions compute the accumulation of the input vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ accum\_sum = \sum_{i=0}^{N-1} \left(src[i]\right) } \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_accum_f32

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The accumulation result

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The accumulation result

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The accumulation result

Transform Functions

In Andes DSP library, the default resolution is set to 1024 (the logarithm of 1024 to base 2 is 10). This default value determines the resolution of cosine and sine lookup tables, i.e., the number of elements in the tables. It also impacts transform functions, as these functions rely on the tables to retrieve cosine or sine values.

This section provides suggested input vector sizes for transform functions to optimize performance. You can identify these values through the function parameter m or the compilation option FFT_LOGN in the examples. While using non-suggested input vector sizes is possible, it may result in reduced accuracy.

Overflow may occur in Q31 and Q15 transform functions. To avoid this, perform an arithmetic right shift operation before calling these functions. The required shift amount depends on the input format, which varies based on the input size. For details about input formats, see the notes on the respective Q31 and Q15 transform functions in their corresponding subsections.

Complex Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) Functions

Functions in this section internally call radix-2 or radix-4 CFFT/CIFFT functions based on the m parameter, which represents log2 (log2 is read as log to the base 2) of the input sample size. If m is a multiple of two (e.g., 4 or 6), radix-4 functions are used for faster performance. Otherwise, radix-2 functions are used.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

Overflow may occur in Q31 and Q15 Radix-4 CFFT and CIFFT functions. To avoid this, perform an arithmetic right shift operation before calling these functions.

riscv_dsp_cfft_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_cfft_f32 (float32_t * src, uint32_t m)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in, out] src

Pointer to the input vector. After the function is executed, the output is stored in the input vector.

[in] m

Represents log2 of the sample number, which can be set between 3 and 10
Returns

None

Example

Given 128 samples (that is, FFT_LOGN = 7), the following is an example of floating-point CFFT and CIFFT functions:

#define FFT_LOGN    7
float32_t src[2* (1 << FFT_LOGN)] = {...};
int32_t ret;
riscv_dsp_cfft_f32 (src, FFT_LOGN);
riscv_dsp_cifft_f32 (src, FFT_LOGN);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, and Q15 CFFT and CIFFT functions.

riscv_dsp_cifft_f32

[in, out] src

Pointer to the input vector. After the function is executed, the output is stored in the input vector.

[in] m

Represents log2 of the sample number, which can be set between 3 and 10
Returns

None

Q1.15

Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) Type II Functions

These functions implement DCT with the following equation:

\[ \mathtt{y}[\mathtt{k}] = \sum_{\mathtt{n}=\scriptscriptstyle{0}}^{\mathtt{N}-\scriptscriptstyle{1}} \mathtt{x}[\mathtt{n}] * \cos\left({\mathtt{\pi * (2 * n + 1)}} * \frac{\mathtt{k}}{\mathtt{(2 * N)}}\right) \]

and IDCT (DCT Type III, also called as the inverse of DCT II), with:

\[ \mathtt{x}[\mathtt{k}] = \frac{\mathtt{2}}{\mathtt{N}} * \sum_{\mathtt{n}=\scriptscriptstyle{0}}^{\mathtt{N}-\scriptscriptstyle{1}} \mathtt{c}[\mathtt{n}] * \mathtt{y}[\mathtt{n}] * \cos\left({\mathtt{\pi * (2 * k + 1)}} * \frac{\mathtt{n}}{\mathtt{(2 * N)}}\right) \]

where

\[\mathtt{c[n] = 1 / 2} \, \, \text{when} \, \, \mathtt{n = 0}, \, \, \text{and} \, \, \mathtt{c[n] = 1} \, \, \text{when} \, \, \mathtt{n \neq 0}.\]

 

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

For DCT type II and IDCT functions in the Q31 and Q15 data type formats, you may apply an arithmetic right shift before calling them.

riscv_dsp_dct_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dct_f32 (float32_t * src, uint32_t m)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in, out] src

Pointer to the input vector. After the function is executed, the output is stored in the input vector.

[in] m

Represents log2 of the sample number, which can be set between 3 and 8
Returns

None

Example

Given 128 samples (that is, FFT_LOGN = 8), the following is an example of floating-point DCT type II and IDCT functions:

#define FFT_LOGN    8
float32_t src[(1 << FFT_LOGN)] = {...};
riscv_dsp_dct_f32 (src, FFT_LOGN);
riscv_dsp_idct_f32 (src, FFT_LOGN);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 DCT type II and IDCT functions.

riscv_dsp_idct_f32

Declaration

Discrete Cosine Transform Type IV (DCT4) Functions

These functions implement DCT transform with the following equation:

\[ \mathtt{y}[\mathtt{k}] = \sum_{\mathtt{n}=\scriptscriptstyle{0}}^{\mathtt{N}-\scriptscriptstyle{1}} \mathtt{x}[\mathtt{n}] * \cos\left({\mathtt{\pi * (2 * k + 1)}} * \frac{\mathtt{(2 * n + 1)}}{\mathtt{(4 * N)}}\right) \]

and IDCT4 with:

\[ \mathtt{x}[\mathtt{k}] = \frac{\mathtt{2}}{\mathtt{N}} * \sum_{\mathtt{n}=\scriptscriptstyle{0}}^{\mathtt{N}-\scriptscriptstyle{1}} \mathtt{y}[\mathtt{n}] * \cos\left({\mathtt{\pi * (2 * k + 1)}} * \frac{\mathtt{(2 * n + 1)}}{\mathtt{(4 * N)}}\right) \]

 

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

For Q31 and Q15 DCT and IDCT type IV functions, you may apply an arithmetic right shift before calling them.

riscv_dsp_dct4_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dct4_f32 (float32_t * src, uint32_t m)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in, out] src

Pointer to the input vector. After the function is executed, the output is stored in the input vector.

[in] m

Represents log2 of the sample number, which can be set between 3 and 7
Returns

None

Example

Given 128 samples (that is, FFT_LOGN = 7), the following is an example of floating-point DCT or IDCT type IV transform functions:

#define FFT_LOGN    8
float32_t src[(1 << FFT_LOGN)] = {...};
riscv_dsp_dct4_f32 (src, FFT_LOGN);
riscv_dsp_idct4_f32 (src, FFT_LOGN);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 DCT and IDCT type IV functions.

Q2.14

Real Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) Functions

Real FFT functions include real fast Fourier transform (RFFT) and inverse fast Fourier transform (RIFFT) functions, which transform signals composed of real values from time domain to frequency domain.

The RFFT algorithm treats the N real data in the input as N/2 complex and performs a CFFT. After the CFFT is computed, the real value at N/2 of the frequency spectrum is stored at the first imaginary position.

The output layout of the RFFT is thus arranged as [r[0], r[N/2], r[1], i[1], …​, r[N/2 - 1], i[N/2 - 1]] where r is real, i is imaginary, and N is the size of the input data.

As no additional array is created during the transformation, the size of the output is identical to that of the input.

As to the RIFFT, its input data has the same format as the output of the RFFT and its output data after computation is converted from the frequency spectrum to the time domain.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

For Q31 and Q15 RFFT and RIFFT functions, you may apply an arithmetic right shift before calling them.

riscv_dsp_rfft_f32

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_rfft_f32 (float32_t * src, uint32_t m)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in, out] src

Pointer to the input vector. After the function is executed, the output is stored in the input vector.

[in] m

Represents log2 of the sample number, which can be set between 4 and 10
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if transformation fails

Example

Given 128 samples (that is, FFT_LOGN = 7), the following is an example of floating-point RFFT and RIFFT functions:

#define FFT_LOGN    7
float32_t src[(1 << FFT_LOGN)] = {...};
int32_t ret;
ret = riscv_dsp_rfft_f32 (src, FFT_LOGN);
if (ret == 0)
    Success
else
    Fail

ret = riscv_dsp_rifft_f32 (src, FFT_LOGN);
if (ret == 0)
    Success
else
    Fail

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, F64, Q31, and Q15 RFFT and RIFFT functions.

riscv_dsp_rifft_f32

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_rifft_f32 (float32_t * src, uint32_t m)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in, out] src

Pointer to the input vector. After the function is executed, the output is stored in the input vector.

[in] m

Represents log2 of the sample number, which can be set between 4 and 10
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if transformation fails

Represents log2 of the sample number, which can be set between 4 and 10
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if transformation fails

Note

The input and output formats are listed below. To satisfy the input format corresponding to your input size, perform an arithmetic shift operation before calling this function.

m Size Input Format Output Format

4

16

Q6.26

Q1.31

5

32

Q7.25

Q1.31

6

64

Q8.24

Q1.31

7

128

Q9.23

Q1.31

8

256

Q10.22

Q1.31

9

512

Q11.21

Q1.31

10

1024

Q12.20

Q1.31

riscv_dsp_rfft_q15

Declaration
int32_t riscv_dsp_rfft_q15 (q15_t * src, uint32_t m)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in, out] src

Pointer to the input vector. After the function is executed, the output is stored in the input vector.

[in] m

Represents log2 of the sample number, which can be set between 4 and 10
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if transformation fails

Note

The input and output formats are listed below. To satisfy the input format corresponding to your input size, perform an arithmetic shift operation before calling this function.

m Size Input Format Output Format

16

Q1.15

Q6.10

5

32

Q1.15

Q7.9

6

Q1.15

Q8.8

7

128

Q1.15

Q9.7

8

256

Q1.15

Q10.6

9

512

Q1.15

Q11.5

10

Q1.15

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if transformation fails

4

Q6.10

10

Q12.4

Q1.15

Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) Transform Functions

Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) are features that collectively form a Mel-Frequency Cepstrum (MFC). They are commonly derived from a cepstral representation of an audio clip through the following process:

  • Perform a Fourier transform on a windowed segment of a signal.

  • Map the resulting power spectrum onto the mel scale using triangular or cosine overlapping windows.

  • Take the logs of the powers at each mel frequency.

  • Apply the discrete cosine transform (DCT) to the list of mel log powers, treating it as a signal.

  • MFCCs are the amplitudes of the resulting spectrum.

To ensure correct results when using the MFCC function, you must initialize the structure with the corresponding initialization function (e.g., riscv_dsp_mfcc_init_f32) before calling the MFCC function (e.g., riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32).

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_mfcc_init_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mfcc_init_f32 (riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32_t * instance, uint32_t fft_len, uint32_t n_mel_filters, uint32_t n_dct_out, float32_t * dct_coefs, uint32_t * filter_pos, uint32_t * filter_len, float32_t * filter_coefs, float32_t * window_coefs)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 MFCC function, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t fft_len;
    uint32_t n_mel_filters;
    uint32_t n_dct_out;
    float32_t * dct_coefs;
    uint32_t * filter_pos;
    uint32_t * filter_len;
    float32_t * filter_coefs;
    float32_t * window_coefs;
    uint32_t log2_fft_len;
} riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32_t;

where:

fft_len

RFFT length

n_mel_filters

Number of Mel filters

n_dct_out

Number of DCT outputs

dct_coefs

Internal DCT coefficients

filter_pos

Internal mel filter positions in the spectrum

filter_len

Internal mel filter lengths

filter_coefs

Internal mel filter coefficients

window_coefs

Window coefficients

log2_fft_len

Represents log2 of FFT length

[out] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] fft_len

RFFT length

[in] n_mel_filters

Number of Mel filters

[in] n_dct_out

Number of DCT outputs

[in] dct_coefs

Pointer to the DCT coefficients vector

[in] filter_pos

Pointer to the mel filter positions vector

[in] filter_len

Pointer to the mel filter lengths vector

[in] filter_coefs

Pointer to the mel filter coefficients vector

[in] window_coefs

Pointer to the window coefficients vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32 (const riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, float32_t * buf)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 MFCC function, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t fft_len;
    uint32_t n_mel_filters;
    uint32_t n_dct_out;
    float32_t * dct_coefs;
    uint32_t * filter_pos;
    uint32_t * filter_len;
    float32_t * filter_coefs;
    float32_t * window_coefs;
    uint32_t log2_fft_len;
} riscv_dsp_mfcc_f32_t;

where:

fft_len

RFFT length

n_mel_filters

Number of Mel filters

n_dct_out

Number of DCT outputs

dct_coefs

Internal DCT coefficients

filter_pos

Internal mel filter positions in the spectrum

filter_len

Internal mel filter lengths

filter_coefs

Internal mel filter coefficients

window_coefs

Window coefficients

log2_fft_len

Represents log2 of FFT length

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] buf

Pointer to the temporary buffer
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Utils Functions

This section includes the following utils functions.

Arc Tangent Functions

These functions are the inverse of trigonometric functions, returning the inverse of tangent for a given an input value. The input values and output results of arc tangent functions are in radians and the output results are always in the range [-π/2, π/2].

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_atan_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_atan_f32 (float32_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value (radian)
Returns

The radian value

Example
float32_t src = 0.5;
float32_t dst;
dst = riscv_dsp_atan_f32 (src);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of Q31 and Q15 arc tangent functions.

riscv_dsp_atan_q31

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_atan_q31 (q31_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value (radian)
Returns

The radian value

riscv_dsp_atan_q15

Declaration
q15_t riscv_dsp_atan_q15 (q15_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value (radian)
Returns

The radian value

Arc Tangent 2 Functions

These functions are similar to arc tangent functions but accept two inputs x and y to compute the inverse tangent value.

Typically, the output results are all in radians and always in the range [-π, π]. For easier calculation, they are mapped to [-1, 1) in Q number functions and can be converted to floating-point using formulas.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_atan2_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_atan2_f32 (float32_t y, float32_t x)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] y

Input value y

[in] x

Input value x
Returns

The radian value

Note

The returned value is in floating-point format and always within the range [-π, π].

riscv_dsp_atan2_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_atan2_f16 (float16_t y, float16_t x)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] y

Input value y

[in] x

Input value x
Returns

The radian value

Note

  • The returned value is in floating-point format and always within the range [-π, π].

  • This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_atan2_q31

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_atan2_q31 (q31_t y, q31_t x)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] y

Input value y

[in] x

Input value x
Returns

The radian value

Note

  • The returned value is in Q31 format and always within the range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF], namely, [-1, 1).

  • To convert the value to the floating-point format, apply the following formula:

    \[ \mathtt{floating\_point\_value = \frac{(returned\_value * \pi)}{2^{31}}} \]

riscv_dsp_atan2_q15

Declaration
q15_t riscv_dsp_atan2_q15 (q15_t y, q15_t x)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] y

Input value y

[in] x

Input value x
Returns

The radian value

Note

  • The returned value is in Q15 format and always within the range [0x8000, 0x7FFF], namely, [-1, 1).

  • To convert the value to the floating-point format, apply the following formula:

    \[ \mathtt{floating\_point\_value = \frac{(returned\_value * \pi)}{2^{15}}} \]

Cosine and Sine Functions

These functions compute the cosine and sine values.

The input values for these functions are in radians, with ranges differing between floating-point and Q number functions.

For floating-point functions, there is no limitation on the input range. Any input value is pre-processed into the range [-2π, 2π] using the following snippet:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{src = abs(src);} \\ & \mathtt{while \, (src \geq 2\pi)} \\ & \{ \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{src -= 2\pi;} \\ & \} \end{aligned} \]

where \(\mathtt{src}\) represents the input value.

Q number (Q31 and Q15) functions support only the input range [-1, 1), corresponding to the Q format range [-π, π]. Therefore, input values must be converted to the Q format range before calling these functions.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_cos_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_cos_f32 (float32_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value (radian)
Returns

The cosine value of the input

Example
float32_t src = 0.5;
float32_t dst;
dst = riscv_dsp_cos_f32 (src);

This example also serves as a reference for examples of F16, Q31, and Q15 cosine and sine functions.

riscv_dsp_cos_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_cos_f16 (float16_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value (radian)
Returns

The cosine value of the input

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_cos_q31 (q31_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value (radian)
Returns

The cosine value of the input

Note

The input range is [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF] and mapped to the range [-π, π].

Note

The input range is [0x8000, 0x7FFF] and mapped to the range [-π, π].

Conversion Functions

These functions convert element values in a source vector from one data type to another and store the results in a destination vector.

The following data type conversions are supported:

float32_t -> float16_t
float32_t -> float64_t
float32_t -> q31_t
float32_t -> q15_t
float32_t -> q7_t
float16_t -> float32_t
float16_t -> float64_t
float16_t -> q15_t
float64_t -> float32_t
float64_t -> float16_t
float64_t -> q31_t
float64_t -> q15_t
float64_t -> q7_t
q31_t -> float32_t
q31_t -> float64_t
q31_t -> q15_t
q31_t -> q7_t
q15_t -> float32_t
q15_t -> float16_t
q15_t -> float64_t
q15_t -> q31_t
q15_t -> q7_t
q7_t -> float32_t
q7_t -> float64_t
q7_t -> q31_t
q7_t -> q15_t

These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_convert_f32_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_f32_f16 (float32_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • This function converts values from float32_t to float16_t.

  • This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_convert_f32_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_f32_f64 (float32_t * src, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function converts values from float32_t to float64_t.

riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q31

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q31 (float32_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • This function converts values from float32_t to q31_t.

  • The results are saturated to the Q31 range [0x80000000, 0x7FFFFFFF].

riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q15 (float32_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • This function converts values from float32_t to q15_t.

  • The results are saturated to the Q15 range [0x8000, 0x7FFF].

riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_f32_q7 (float32_t * src, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • This function converts values from float32_t to q7_t.

  • The results are saturated to the Q7 range [0x80, 0x7F].

For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_convert_q31_q15

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_q31_q15 (q31_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • This function converts values from q31_t to q15_t.

  • No overflow occurs since the values are simply right-shifted by 16 bits.

riscv_dsp_convert_q31_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_q31_q7 (q31_t * src, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

  • This function converts values from q31_t to q7_t.

  • No overflow occurs since the values are simply right-shifted by 24 bits.

riscv_dsp_convert_q15_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_q15_f32 (q15_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)

Pointer to the output vector

Declaration

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function converts values from q15_t to q31_t by left-shifting them 16 bits.

riscv_dsp_convert_q15_q7

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_convert_q15_q7 (q15_t * src, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function converts values from q15_t to q7_t by right-shifting them 8 bits.

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function converts values from q7_t to q15_t by left-shifting them 8 bits.

Duplicate Functions

These functions copy element values from a source vector and store the results one-by-one in a destination vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = src[n];} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_dup_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dup_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_dup_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dup_f16 (float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_dsp_dup_f64

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_dup_f64 (float64_t * src, float64_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Set Functions

These functions set all elements in a destination vector to a constant value.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \begin{aligned} & \mathtt{for \ (n = 0; \, \, n < size; \, \, n++)} \\ & \quad \quad \mathtt{dst[n] = value;} \end{aligned} \]

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_set_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_set_f32 (float32_t val, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] val

Value to be written to the output vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_set_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_set_f16 (float16_t val, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)

Value to be written to the output vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Square Root (SQRT) Functions

These functions return the square root value of the input.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point, Q31, and Q15. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_sqrt_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_sqrt_f32 (float32_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value
Returns

The square root of the input

riscv_dsp_sqrt_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_sqrt_f16 (float16_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value
Returns

The square root of the input

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Declaration
q31_t riscv_dsp_sqrt_q31 (q31_t src)

[in] src

Input value
Returns

The square root of the input

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value
Returns

The square root of the input

Barycenter Functions

These functions calculate the barycenter of the input vector.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_barycenter_f32

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_barycenter_f32 (const float32_t * src, const float32_t * weights, float32_t * dst, uint32_t numofvec, uint32_t dimofvec)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] weights

Pointer to the weighted vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] numofvec

Number of input vectors

[in] dimofvec

dimension of the vector space
Returns

None

riscv_dsp_barycenter_f16

Declaration
void riscv_dsp_barycenter_f16 (const float16_t * src, const float16_t * weights, float16_t * dst, uint32_t numofvec, uint32_t dimofvec)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] weights

Pointer to the weighted vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] numofvec

Number of input vectors

[in] dimofvec

dimension of the vector space
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Weighted Sum Functions

These functions calculate the weighted sum of the input vector.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_weighted_sum_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_weighted_sum_f32 (const float32_t * src, const float32_t * weight, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] weight

Pointer to the weighted vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The weighted sum value

riscv_dsp_weighted_sum_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_dsp_weighted_sum_f16 (const float16_t * src, const float16_t * weight, uint32_t size)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] weight

Pointer to the weighted vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The weighted sum value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Exponential Functions

These functions compute the exponential value of the input value.

Andes DSP library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_dsp_exp_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_dsp_exp_f32 (float32_t src)
Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value
Returns

The exponential value of the input

Declaration

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Input value
Returns

The exponential value of the input

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains with HW FPU support. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both the compiler and linker flags for applications that use this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.
